talk.start.para: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to honourable member's question:

answer.para: Until recently, the Child Support Agency (CSA) did not retain information which could be extracted from the computer system relating to previous addresses when a change of address was notified. Therefore, the information requested as at 1 January 1996 and 1 January 1997 is unavailable.
The following table represents CSA clients (both payers and payees) as at 1 January 1998:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 June 1998:

question.para: Further to the answer to question No. 1504 (Hansard , 2 June 1997, page 4650), what are the (a) names, (b) positions and (c) qualifications of the persons who will represent Australia at the meeting of Governmental Experts on the Draft Convention on the Protection of Underwater Cultural Heritage to be held at UNESCO headquarters, Paris, from 29 June to 2 July 1998.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) and (b) The Australian delegation to the meeting of Governmental Experts on the Draft Copnvention on the Protection of Underwater Cultural Heritage, from 29 June to 2 July, will be:
Mr Peter Shannon, Permanent Delegate of Australia to UNESCO, former Head of the Law of the Sea Unit and a former Deputy Legal Adviser in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade;
Mr David Walker, Alternate Permanent Delegate of Australia to UNESCO;
Ms Carolyn Irving, Third Secretary and member of the Permanent Delegation of Australia to UNESCO.
(c) Mr Shannon has a Bachelor of Laws/Bachelor of Arts degree. Mr Walker and Ms Irving have Bachelor of Arts degrees.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 3 June 1998:

question.para: (1) Did the Commonwealth allocate $2.6 million through the Australian National Training Authority (ANTA) for capital works at the Institute for Aboriginal Development in Alice Springs; if so, what are the details.
(2) Has the Institute for Aboriginal Development received other Commonwealth funding for infrastructure improvements.
(3) In allocating the $2.6 million, did the ANTA Ministerial Council indicate its support for the work done and the results achieved by the Institute for Aboriginal Development.
(4) Did the Report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody specifically recommend support for institutions such as the Institute for Aboriginal Development.
(5) What steps has he taken to ensure that the ANTA capital works funding will be spent as soon as possible.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Under the Vocational Education and Training Act 1992, introduced by the previous Labor Government, the Commonwealth provides funding to the Australian National Training Authority (ANTA) for the infrastructure programme including, from 1996-1998, $15 million to help address the infrastructure needs of Indigenous vocational education and training providers. ANTA is responsible for the allocation of funds. ANTA has allocated, but not yet paid, $2.6 million to the Northern Territory Government for capital works at the Institute for Aboriginal Development.

(3) The ANTA Ministerial Council agrees the indicative allocation of infrastructure funds between States and Territories and the amount to be allocated to Skill Centres and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander facilities. ANTA administers the programme, including settling with States and Territories individual projects.

(4) The Report recommended, among other things, that "Governments support Aboriginal community controlled adult education institutions and other institutions which provide a programme of courses which have the support of the Aboriginal community". (Recommendation 298a)
(5) The Institute for Aboriginal Development has been encouraged to negotiate with the Northern Territory Government a resolution to the issue of the appropriate site for the capital works.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 22 June 1998:

question.para: Further to the answer to question No. 2777 (Hansard , 14 May 1998, page 3522), in which he advised that since the answer to question No. 1871 (Hansard , 23 September 1997, page 8257) was given, there have been no formal complaints made by industrial associations to the International Labour Organisation (ILO) concerning Australian industrial law and practice, is it a fact that the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions lodged a complaint with the ILO in Geneva on 7 May 1998 alleging some 9 breaches of Australia's treaty obligations under ILO conventions; if so, will he (a) correct the record by advising of the nature of the complaint and (b) provide a copy of the Government's response to the complaint.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Since the answer to question No. 2777 was given, the Government has received advice from the International Labour Organisation (ILO) that a complaint has been lodged with the ILO's Committee on Freedom of Association by the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions (ICFTU) about aspects of the waterfront dispute. The complaint was lodged on 7 May 1998 and the Government received formal advice of the complaint from the ILO on 25 May 1998.

(a) The complaint concerns alleged breaches of ILO Convention No. 87 Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise, 1948 and Convention No. 98, Right to Organise and Collective Bargaining, 1949.

(b) Receipt of the ILO's letter and the copy of the complaint was acknowledged on 2 June 1998. The Government also advised the ILO that the ICFTU's claims are completely rejected and foreshadowed a detailed response to be provided in time for the Committee's consideration at its next meeting (November 1998).

The response will be set out in the Committee's report on the complaint. It is not the practice of Australian governments to publish a response to a complaint to the Committee before the Committee has dealt with the matter.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 22 June 1998:

question.para: (1) Does he support Commonwealth financing of the proposed redevelopment of Campbelltown sports ground for the benefit of the Western Suburbs Rugby League Football Club and other sporting organisations in the Macarthur district.
(2) Will the Government match the financial contributions to the project made by the NSW Government and Campbelltown City Council.
(3) What efforts has he made to secure Commonwealth funding of this project from the Centenary of Federation fund.

(4) Did he support the recent use of the Centenary of Federation fund to help finance the redevelopment of the Gosford sports ground for the benefit of the North Sydney Rugby League Football Club; if so, what are the details.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: As Member for Macarthur, I wrote to the Prime Minister on 20 April in relation to a proposal for redevelopment of a regional sporting complex that would include an upgrade of the Campbelltown Sports Stadium. I supported the proposal as I felt it would be of considerable social and economic benefit to the South West area of Sydney. On 29 June I supported a submission by the Campbelltown City Council to Senator the Hon Richard Alston, Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, for funding under the Federation Cultural and Heritage programme.
The issue of matching financial contributions to projects is one for Government consideration. There are numerous projects of merit lodged for consideration.
As I have already indicated, I have written to the Prime Minister in support of the project. I will continue to actively and strongly highlight the merits of the project.

I support projects that will provide considerable social and economic benefit to the community. On 30 May 1998, the Government announced inclusion of the redevelopment of Grahame Park, Gosford to a regional recreational complex as a project that would receive assistance under the Federation Fund.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 29 June 1998:

question.para: (1) What information is available on the uses of nicotinic acid as a possible treatment to assist recovery from past alcoholism.
(2) Have nicotinic acid tablets recently been removed from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme list for veterans; if so, why.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Nicotinic acid is currently not regarded as a useful treatment for any aspect of past alcoholism. The USPDI 1998 states that nicotinic acid has not been proven effective in the treatment of alcohol dependence.

There are many treatments for past alcoholism currently available. At present, benzodiazepines such as diazepam are the drugs of choice to assist in the control of withdrawal symptoms. Other treatments include the use of disulfiram, maintenance of fluid balance, and large doses of vitamin C and B-complex vitamins, particularly thiamine. Although nicotinic acid is a B-group vitamin (B3), its inclusion in a vitamin B-rich complex as part of therapy has no significance other than to replenish the patient's depleted stores of the vitamin. Alcoholism will commonly deplete the body of vitamin C and B-group vitamins, especially thiamine (B1).
(2) Nicotinic acid 250mg tablets remain currently listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS). Eligible Veterans are entitled to receive all PBS-listed drugs at the concessional rate.

On 1 August 1990, two strengths of nicotinic acid tablets (25mg and 50mg) were removed from the PBS. This delisting was due to lack of evidence for the efficacy of low doses of nicotinic acid in the treatment of hyperlipidaemia. It is to be noted that the major use of nicotinic acid is in the treatment of hyperlipidaemia, but may also be used as a vasodilator, or as a supplement in vitamin B3 deficiency.
QUESTIONS ON NOTICE
The following answers to questions were circulated after the rising of the House of Representatives on 15 July 1998 and before the prorogation of the Parliament on 31 August 1998:

subdebateinfo.title: Victorian Foundation for Survivors of Torture: Funding
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2671)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: Has the Commonwealth funded the Victorian Foundation for Survivors of Torture; if so, (a) under what category was the funding provided, (b) what tendering process was followed, (c) how many organisations applied for funding, (d) did the Foundation receive additional funding for the purchase of major capital items such as vehicles; if so, under which funding round, (e) for what period has the funding been allocated under the service agreement between him and the Foundation, (f) what were the Foundation's client outcomes in 1996-97, (g) were the outcomes considered in the tendering process and (h) does the Foundation receive recurrent funding; if so, for how many positions.

talk.start.para: —The following is a supplementary answer to the answer previously supplied to the honourable member (Hansard 1 April 1998, page 2332):

answer.para: (a) In addition to funds provided under the Community Settlement Services Scheme (worker based) category, payment was made to the Victorian Foundation for Survivors of Torture Inc (VFST) through the Asylum Seeker Assistance (ASA) Scheme. The ASA Scheme is administered by the Australian Red Cross Society (ARCS) under an Agreement with the Commonwealth of Australia. Monies were forwarded to the VFST by ARCS during 1997-98 under two separate Agreements:

. from July 1997- April 1998 under the Agreement between the Commonwealth of Australia and the ARCS in relation to the provision of a Grant for the ASA Scheme for 1995-96, which was extended until 30 April 1998; and,
. from May—June 1998 under the recently signed Agreement between the Commonwealth of Australia and the ARCS in relation to the administration of the ASA Scheme for 1997-99.
(b) No tendering process was followed. The VFST is a sub-contractor under the ASA Agree ment between the Commonwealth of Australia and the ARCS.
(c) Not applicable.
(d) No.
(e) The funding has been allocated for the period 1 July 1997 to 30 June 1999 under the two separate ASA Agreements as detailed at (a) above.

(f) The VFST was not funded in 1996-97 under the ASA Agreement. Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs funding of the VFST during that period is detailed in the response provided in Hansard 1 April 1998 page 2332.
(g) Not applicable.
(h) See answer to (e). Payment is based on the number of clients referred by the Australian Red Cross.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 10 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an offer by MBF to BHP coal employees in Central Queensland for a special cut-rate health insurance cover which is promoted as being underwritten by MBF.

(2) Is it a fact that (a) MBF is reinsured with the Health Benefits Reinsurance Trust Fund and (b) the reinsurance was to a total of $15.6 million for the 1997 September quarter; if so, is the scheme referred to in part (1) being subsidised by that reinsurance.
(3) Does the use of reinsurance subsidisation place an unfair impost on funds with stable or increasing membership.
(4) Does the reduction in membership and increased fees for larger health funds penalise smaller health funds through the reinsurance system.
(5) Has the reinsurance subsidy system been scrutinised by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I am aware that MBF is offering employer sponsored private health insurance to BHP employees.
(2) (a) Yes, as are all registered private health insurance funds.
(b) The amount was in fact $15.5 million. No, this is not subsidising the offer to BHP.
(5) No. It was subjected to scrutiny by the Industry Commission in Report 57 released on 28 February 1997.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs: Labour Hire Firms
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2757)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 11 March 1998:

question.para: (1) How many persons have worked in each department, agency, Commonwealth authority and company, including government business enterprises, for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility under a contract for services entered into with a firm whose sole or predominant business is the hiring of labour to clients (a) in 1996-97 and (b) between 1 July 1997 and 28 February 1998.
(2) In what sections of the department, agency, authority or company were the persons referred to in part (1) employed.
(3) What are the names of the labour-hire firms referred to in part (1) which provided services (a) in 1996-97 and (b) between 1 July 1997 and 28 February 1998.
(4) How were the labour-hire firms selected.

(10) What total sum was paid to labour-hire firms in total (a) in 1996-97 and (b) between 1 July 1997 and 28 February 1998.

(11) What projected labour requirement will be met by labour-hire firms in the departments, agencies, Commonwealth authorities or companies, including government business enterprises, for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility from (a) February to June 1998 and (b) July 1998 to June 1999.

(12) How many government employees have been replaced through labour provided by labour-hire firms in each department, agency, Commonwealth authority and company, including government business enterprises, for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) How many persons have worked in each department, agency, Commonwealth authority and company, including government business enterprises, for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility under a contract for services entered into with a firm whose sole or predominant business is the hiring of labour to clients (a) in 1996-97 and (b) between 1 July 1997 and 28 February 1998.

answer.para: (b) between 1 July 1997 and 28 February 1998

Key People Personnel P/L, Andersen, Axis, Candle Computer, CCA Software, Computer People, CP Resourcing, Drake, Eurolink, Key People, MC Computing, Parity People, Paxus, Praxa Ltd, Price Waterhouse, Quasar Professionals, Southern Cross Computing, Stirling Software, Stratagem, Walter and Turnbull, Warildi, Wizard.

Equus People Pty Ltd (Career People), Morgan and Banks Management Services Pty Ltd, Drake International.

Andersen, Answerz, Aspect Computing, Aust Communications, Axis Computing, Brio Technology, Candle Computer Service, Cisco, Computer People, Corporate Consulting, CP Resourcing, CPIC, DMR Consulting, Eurolink, Ferntree, Glendar Consulting, HDS, MC Computing, Parity People, Paxus, Praxa Ltd, Southern Cross, Stratagem, Wizard.
Key People Personnel, All Staff Australia Pty Ltd, Wizard Information Services.

answer.para: (4) How were the labour-hire firms selected.

entry.para: National Office of Overseas Skills Recognition: the initial contractual arrangements with Omega Personnel were for a small number of short term contracts. These contracts were awarded after three (3) written quotes were obtained. In 1995 a long term relationship was established with Omega Personnel to avoid delays and costs relating to training new contractors. Higher Education Research Branch: Green and Green and Omega Personnel were both selected through public tender after eight (8) tenders were received. The following year, Green and Green and Western Staff Services were selected through select tender where ten (10) agencies were approached.

Key People Personnel Pty Ltd was appointed under a Common Use Arrangement with the former Department of Administrative Services for the provision of data entry bureau services to APS departments located in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). The remainder of the firms used by Operations and Performance Division were appointed under Common Use Arrangements administered by the former Department of Administrative Services, followed by a Request for Quote process by the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs.
Phoenix Contracting Pty Ltd was approached as a firm known for their industry knowledge and expertise and for their ability to provide staff at very short notice.
International, Equity, Youth and Students Division

Policy, Research and Analysis Section: requested quotes from four (4) labour-hire firms. International Communications and Marketing Section: all potential external service providers in the ACT were approached. A panel was established of those providers who expressed an interest from which contract staff could be drawn.
The company was appointed under a Common Use Arrangement with the Department.
National Board of Employment, Education and Training
Requested quotes from three (3) labour-hire firms.

Southern Queensland: The firm was chosen through standard public tender processes. Cairns: Requested quotes from three (3) labour-hire firms. Townsville: Request for Expressions of Interest sent to three (3) providers in the Townsville area. Townsville Labour Market Programs: Requested quotes from four (4) labour-hire firms.

State and Area Offices: The firm was chosen through a public tender process managed by Purchasing Australia. The contract was extended in November 1996 on advice from Purchasing Australia. Student Assistance Centres: Key People was appointed under a Common Use Arrangement initiated by Youth, Students and Social Policy Division (or its predecessor) in National Office.
The firms were appointed under DAS Common Use Arrangement PE68—Supply of IT Services.

Wizard Information Services was selected through Systems Division following a select tender process (29 tenders were received). Key People Personnel and All Staff Australia Pty Ltd: quotes were requested from nine (9) firms.
Drake Overload and the Personnel Department were approached as firms known for their ability to provide staff with specialised skills at extremely short notice.

Key People Personnel Pty Ltd were appointed under a Common Use Arrangement administered by the former Department of Administrative Services. Wizard Information Services Pty Ltd: Requested quotes from six (6) firms and Wizard Personnel and Office Services: requested a quote from only one (1) firm due to the value of the contract.
Library Locums Pty Ltd was appointed under a Common Use Arrangement administered by the former Department of Administrative Services.

answer.para: (5) Will the Minister provide a copy of the tender documents in each case where a labour-hire firm was selected by public tender.

entry.para: For the labour-hire firms which were selected through public tender processes, the Minister will provide Request for Tender documents should they be requested.
For the labour-hire firms which were selected through public tender processes, the Minister will provide Request for Tender documents should they be requested.
The tender process was managed by Purchasing Australia.
For the labour-hire firms which were selected through public tender processes, the Minister will provide Request for Tender documents should they be requested.

answer.para: (6) Will the Minister provide a copy of the terms of reference for the selection of labour-hire firms.
The `Terms of Reference' included in the public tender documents issued by the Department will be provided should they be requested.
(7) Who comprised the selection panel for successful tenders.

entry.para: The panel comprised representatives from the area who were users of the services.
Southern Queensland: The panel comprised representatives from the Student Assistance Centres—either the Manager or their representative.
The tender process was managed by Purchasing Australia.
The Systems Contract Management Team managed the Wizard Information Services Contract.

answer.para: (8) What commission was payable by each department, agency, authority or company to each labour-hire firm for each person contracted for labour.

The Department considers that it would be inappropriate to allocate the resources necessary to answer this question as it would require contacting all contractors to seek their agreement to public release of this information.
(9) What total sum (a) is owed and (b) was paid to each labour-hire firm.

The Department considers that it would be inappropriate to allocate the resources necessary to answer this question as it would require contacting all contractors to seek their agreement to public release of this information.
(10) What total sum was paid to labour-hire firms in total (a) in 1996-97 and (b) between 1 July 1997 and 28 February 1998.

(11) What projected labour requirement will be met by labour-hire firms in the departments, agencies, Commonwealth authorities or companies, including government business enterprises, for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility from (a) February to June 1998 and (b) July 1998 to June 1999.

The Department does not have projections of use of labour-hire firms for the remainder of the year and for subsequent financial years. It is expected that current usage patterns are likely to continue.

(12) How many government employees have been replaced through labour provided by labour-hire firms in each department, agency, Commonwealth authority and company, including government business enterprises, for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility.
Labour-hire firms have been contracted only where requisite technical skills are unavailable within the organisation or to handle seasonal or fluctuating workloads.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, upon notice, on 25 March 1998:

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) A list of the top 20 television programs for the year-to-date (28 December 1997 to 14 March 1998) is attached.
(2) 12 of the 20 most popular programs in this period originated in the UK or Ireland.

(3) In each year the ABC reviews its planned programs to decide if they will proceed. In any given year a number of programs may be cancelled or deferred. In 1997/98 the following programs planned for production were cancelled or deferred. These include:

a reduction in the number of mini-series from four to two
reduction in the funds available for licence fees/investment in independently
produced mini-series
reduction in the number of drama series planned for Sunday evening transmission from two to one.

answer.para: (1) On the basis of information provided by Telstra, Optus and Vodafone, the following towns in New South Wales with populations of at least 1000 persons currently do not have mobile phone coverage:
Boorowa; Brewarrina; Condobolin; Coolamon; Hillston; Kandos; Lake Cargelligo; Peak Hill; Tumbarumba; Walcha.

(2) The three mobile carriers advise that their information systems are unable to provide information in the precise form of the question asked by the honourable member. Telstra has advised, however, that its GSM (digital) service is available in 221 of 243 (91%) of towns greater than 1000 persons and its AMPS (analogue) service is available in 219 of 243 (90%) of such towns. The Optus and Vodafone digital coverage is approximately 92% and 61% respectively.

The recently released report by the Australian Communications Authority (ACA) of its investigation of AMPS regional coverage provides further information on the differences between existing AMPS and GSM coverage.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 8 April 1998:

question.para: (1) On what occasions, on what dates and at which locations has he met with Mr Chris Corrigan of Patrick Stevedores between 2 March 1996 and the date of answering this question.

(2) Is he able to say whether Mr Corrigan as Chairman of Australian Stevedores Ltd proposed to a board meeting in mid-1994 that balance sheet provisions and assets be transferred from the company's Darling Harbour operations to a shelf company in the expectation that the Darling Harbour operations would be run into liquidation so that funds would not be available to pay out creditors including employees' entitlements on termination.
(3) Were copies of an ACIL report prepared at the expense of the Commonwealth provided to Mr Corrigan.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: This question concerns matters relevant to current proceedings in the Federal Court of Australia brought by the Maritime Union of Australia. While those proceedings remain on foot, canvassing these matters outside the Court's processes could prejudice the impartial adjudication of the matter and the rights of the parties to the proceedings.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 8 April 1998:

question.para: Has the Government implemented the major recommendation of the Plane Safe inquiry of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure that major deficiencies detected by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority in general aviation charter aircraft be published each month commencing March 1996; if not, (a) why not and (b) when will the information be made public.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Implementation of all the recommendations of the Plane Safe inquiry remains a priority of the Government.

(a)&(b) The monthly publication of monthly serious deficiency reports is being actively considered by the Government in consultation with the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA). However, a number of substantial issues have arisen which have precluded the publication of reports which would provide meaningful advice to the public.

In addition to definitional and timing issues, CASA has advised that the unrefined publication of data currently available would be inappropriate, potentially misleading and present to operators adverse barriers of a commercial nature. In addition, there are significant legal complexities, including natural justice considerations with regard to operators that are named or identified in a report.

Taking these factors into account, the Government is still strongly committed to implementing the intent of the recommendation, and is of the view that forgoing the provision to the public of information of at least a similar nature is not acceptable. Accordingly, I have asked that a revised, more representative proposal be prepared by CASA as a matter of priority which fully addresses its obligations with respect to this matter.

The CASA Board has advised me of its full support for initiatives that will provide the travelling public with a better understanding of aviation risks. It is also seeking to implement arrangements whereby common standards would apply to an aircraft used for passenger operations irrespective of whether they are charter or regular public transport (RPT) operations.

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Long Term Operating Plan
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2911)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 8 April 1998:

question.para: (1) Have Airservices Australia considered variations to Mode 4 of the Long Term Operating Plan for Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport in particular using both of the parallel runways for landing and take-offs.
(2) Would a variation to Mode 4 enable greater use of Simultaneous Opposite Direction Parallel Runway Operations (SODPROPS) particularly involving large aircraft.
(3) Will Airservices Australia implement variations to Mode 4 to increase the use of SODPROPS.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. Mode 4 involves aircraft landing to the north on the main north-south runway and taking off to the south from the new parallel runway. A variation to Mode 4 which has now been adopted involves a small number of additional aircraft taking off to the north from the main north-south runway but no consideration has been given to using both runways for arrivals.
(2) Yes, but see (1) above.
(3) Procedures to increase the use of Simultaneous Direction Parallel Runway Operations (SODPROPS) came into effect at Sydney Airport on 10 April 1998.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
