(2) under Federal Roads Programs, the division received a proportion of the Queensland allocation of $60.56m for maintenance and $13.64m for minor works;

(3) under the Local Government Financial Assistance Grants, the division received a proportion of the $29,876,760 general purpose grants and local roads grants made to Brisbane City, Ipswich City and Beaudesert Shire; and

(4) under the Regional Development Program, the Ipswich Regional Development Corporation received a proportion of: the $235,000 paid to the Corporation over two years (1996-97 and 1997-98) for administrative expenses, and the $99,365 paid to the Corporation over three years (1995-96 to 1997-98) for an evaluation of telecommunication infrastructure in Ipswich and surrounds.
(1) under Federal Roads Programs, the division will receive a proportion of the Queensland allocation of $57.38m for maintenance and $12.92m for minor works;
At this stage no projects under the Federal Road Safety Black Spot Program have been approved for funding in Queensland in 1998-99.
The allocation of Local Government grants for 1998-99 has yet to be determined by the Queensland Grants Commission.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 12 May 1998:

question.para: Is it a fact that to qualify for exemption from unfair dismissal laws contained in the Workplace Relations Act a small business needs to (a) employ fewer than 15 persons, (b) be a respondent to a federal award and (c) be a constitutional corporation; if so, (a) how many small businesses meet those criteria and (b) what percentage of the total number of employers do they represent.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) There are presently exemptions from the termination of employment provisions under the Workplace Relations Act 1996 that apply to all businesses, including small businesses, such as those in relation to casual and probationary employees.

The Government has also proposed an exemption specifically for small business employers. The proposal is to exclude any new employee (other than an apprentice) of an employer with 1 5 or fewer employees from the provisions on harsh, unjust or unreasonable termination of employment.

However, that exemption is not in place, because the Workplace Relations Amendment Bill 1997 has twice been rejected by the Senate. The Government will continue to pursue this proposal, at the appropriate time.
The exemption would apply to small businesses within the scope of the federal unfair dismissal laws
A small business in Victoria or a Territory is automatically covered by the federal unfair dismissal provisions and therefore would benefit from the proposed federal exemption.
A small business owned or controlled by the Commonwealth would also be automatically covered.

Other small businesses would only be covered by the federal unfair dismissal provisions (and therefore directly benefit from the exemption) if an employee were employed under a federal award or agreement and one of the following applied:
. the small business was a constitutional corporation;
. the small business was engaged in certain interstate or overseas trade or commerce; or

. there was State legislation applying the federal provisions so as to confer jurisdiction (in respect to dismissals by unincorporated employers of employees covered by federal awards or agreements) on the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

(2) It is not possible to specify the number of small businesses which would directly benefit from the Government's proposed exemption from unfair dismissal laws for small businesses, as the operation of the provisions, according to the criteria outlined above, would depend on the details of the interrelationship between federal and State legislation, in each State, at the relevant time.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 12 May 1998:

question.para: Is it a fact that (a) the Australian Industrial Relations Commission's ability to direct parties to an industrial dispute to negotiate in good faith has been removed and (b) section 170QK of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 has been repealed and not replicated in the Workplace Relations Act 1996; if so, why.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) The Industrial Relations Act 1988 did not empower the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to direct parties to negotiate in good faith—see Asahi Diamond Industrial Australia Pty Limited v Automotive, Food, Metals and Engineering Union (1995) 59 IR 385 (`Asahi'). In Asahi, a Full Bench of the Commission, in considering whether the Commission had the power to direct parties to negotiate, said (at p421-422) that:

"[t]he industrial relations system provided by the [Industrial Relations] Act is one which facilitates and encourages direct bargaining underpinned by an effective award safety net. It is not a system of compulsory negotiation.
An agreement cannot be reached with a person who does nor want to agree and negotiations for an agreement cannot take place with a person who does not want to negotiate.

It follows from the ordinary meaning of the word `negotiate' that an order that a person negotiate carries the inference that the Commission is ordering that concessions be made. . .such an order is beyond power.
(b) Section 170QK of the Industrial Relations Act, which was repealed by the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996, did not confer any substantive power—see Asahi at p424.

The Commission's powers with respect to agreements under the Workplace Relations Act 1996 are consistent with the object of giving employers and employees at the workplace or enterprise level greater direct responsibility for matters affecting their relationship—see s.3(b) of the Act.
Under the Workplace Relations Act:

• the Australian Industrial Relations Commission may exercise conciliation powers to assist parties in connection with negotiations for a certified agreement—see s.170NA of the Workplace Relations Act 1996, and parties may be directed to attend conferences—see s.1 1 9. Where parties are unable to reach agreement about a particular matter, they may request the Commission to conduct a hearing and make recommendations about the matter. Such recommendations are binding on the parties—see s.1 1 1 AA. An agreement must be approved by or made with a valid majority of employees, and the terms of any agreement put to employees to consider approving or making must be explained to them—see ss170LJ and 170LK.

• the Commission's powers in connection with Australian workplace agreements relate only to the approval of agreements, variation agreements and termination of agreements—the Commission has no power to make orders in connection with the negotiation of AWAs. However, it is relevant to note a party to an AWA is required to recognise the other party's bargaining agent [s.170VK(2)], an AWA requires the genuine consent of the employee concerned [s.170VPA] and the employer must have explained the effect of the agreement and provided specified information to the employee [ss.170VPA and 170VO]

• under the Coalition's Workplace Relations Act 1996 it is open to the approving authority for workplace agreements, (whether the Office of the Employment Advocate or, in certain circumstances, the AIRC) to consider issues of good faith in deciding whether genuine consent existed at the time agreements were entered into.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business Staff: Drafting Legislation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2944)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 12 May 1998:

question.para: (1) How many persons in his Department worked on the drafting of the Stevedoring Levy (Collection) Bill 1998 and the Stevedoring Levy (Imposition) Bill 1998 and who were they.
(2) On what day did they start work on preparing the bills for introduction to the Parliament.

(3) Were persons outside his Department employed or contracted to draft part of either bill; if so, (a) from what date, (b) for what period (c) who were they, (d) what remuneration did each receive, (e) did he or his staff indicate to his Department whom should be employed or contracted and (f) was a recognised tendering process followed.

(4) Was any person or group outside the Department other than the persons referred to in part (3) consulted about the drafting of the bills; if so, (a) who were they and (b) were they remunerated for the consultation.
(5) Were the draft bills discussed outside the Government before being introduced to the House; if so, (a) with whom, (b) where and when and (c) was he or his staff involved.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows.

answer.para: Six persons employed in the Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business worked, or were consulted, on the drafting of the Stevedoring Levy (Collection) Bill 1998 and the Stevedoring Levy (Imposition) Bill 1998 as follows:
. Dr P Shergold, Secretary;
. Mr R Stewart-Crompton, Deputy Secretary;
. Mr K Bills, First Assistant Secretary, Maritime Transport Division;
. Mr D Gillespie, Assistant Secretary, Waterfront and Maritime Team;
. Mr B Cooper, Waterfront and Maritime Team; and
. Ms R Harrison, Legal Services Branch.

(2) Drafting the request for policy approval for levy legislation applying to both the maritime and stevedoring industry commenced on or about 26 February 1998. Preparation of drafting instructions also commenced on or about 26 February 1998. Drafting instructions were issued on 6 March 1998.
(3) The Office of Parliamentary Counsel drafted the bills. As stated above, drafting instructions were issued on 6 March 1998.
(4) The following persons were consulted about the drafting of the bills:
. I and members of my staff;
. the acting Solicitor-General;
. officers of the Criminal and Civil Law Divisions of the Attorney-General's Department;
. officers of the Office of General Counsel, Australian Government Solicitor;
. representatives of Patrick Stevedores (see below); and
. representatives of P&O Ports (see below).
An invoice for professional fees has been received from the Office of General Counsel.
(5) Draft legislation was discussed with representatives of Patrick Stevedores and P&O Ports as follows:
Patrick:
(a) Mr Corrigan of Patrick, Mr Gray of Freehill Hollingdale and Page, solicitors, and Dr Shergold and Mr Gillespie of my Department;
(b) Sydney, 29 March 1998;
(c) No.
P&O:
1. Meetings
(a) Messrs Hein, Campbell, Setchell, Mason and Russell of P&O Ports and Dr Shergold and Mr Gillespie of my Department;
(b) Sydney, 30 March 1998;
(c) No.
(a) Messrs Hein, Campbell, Setchell, and Mason of P&O Ports and Dr Shergold and Mr Gillespie of my Department;
(b) Canberra, 1 April 1998;
(c) A number of my staff and I attended the meeting.
(a) Mr Mason and Ms Catts of P&O Ports and Dr Shergold and Messrs Gillespie and Cooper of my Department;
(b) Canberra, 2 April 1998;
(c) No.
2. Telephone discussions
(a) Mr Mason of P&O Ports and Mr Cooper of my Department;
(b) On or about 3 April, 11 April and 12 April (note: Mr Gillespie of my Department also participated in the first discussion);
(c) No.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 12 May 1998:

question.para: (1) Has the `One Link' contract made by the Victorian Government for the installation of automated ticketing on Melbourne's railways been examined for compliance with the Commonwealth's Disability Discrimination Act.
(2) What action will he take if the contract through an apparent lack of reference to physical disability, intellectual disability and vision impairment fails to meet the requirements of the Act.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) This is a matter for the Victorian Government. The Commonwealth Government is not in the practice of examining State Government contracts for compliance with Commonwealth legislation.

(2) Again, compliance with the Commonwealth Disability Discrimination Act 1992, and Victoria's own Equal Opportunity Act 1995, is ultimately a matter for the Victorian Government. There is a mechanism under both pieces of legislation for a complaint to be made by a person alleged to have suffered discrimination on the basis of disability. Where such an allegation is sustained, the legislation allows for the making of a range of determinations, including a declaration that the person responsible for the discrimination perform any reasonable act or course of conduct to redress any loss or damage suffered by the complainant.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Health and Family Service Contracts: Standard Requirements
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2948)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 12 May 1998:

question.para: (1) Do all contracts between his Department and community or private service providers in each program require the providers to adhere to the same or similar privacy provisions which apply to the Commonwealth Government.
(2) Does the Commonwealth require providers to meet national standards before and during the provision of service.
(3) Are providers required to be certified, accredited or licensed; if so, by whom.
(4) Are providers required to operate consumer complaints mechanisms during the life of their contracts.
(5) Are there further avenues of complaint if internal complaints procedures do not resolve specific complaints.
(6) Are all services funded through Commonwealth and State or Territory Agreements required to meet the obligations identified in parts (1) to (4).
(7) Are there specific obligations which providers funded through Commonwealth and State or Territory Agreements must meet.
(8) Do sanctions apply to providers not meeting the contractual obligations identified in parts (1) to (4).
(9) By what mechanism does the Commonwealth ensure the providers fulfil the contractual obligations identified in parts (1) to (4).
(10) Are clients of contracted providers able to complain to the Commonwealth Ombudsman as a last resort.
(11) Were consumer or industry organisations involved in the development of the obligations identified in parts (1) to (4); if so, which organisations in relation to which programs.
(12) Are mechanisms established to identify systematic issues of concern to consumers or the industry in relation to the conduct of each program.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: To provide a complete answer to this question would require considerable time and resources to inspect a large number of contracts and, in the interest of efficient utilisation of departmental resources, I am not prepared to ask my Department to divert from existing priorities at this time. However in an effort to assist, general answers can be provided to some of the questions as follows:

(1) The Standard Form Contract for Services that is made available for use by Departmental Officers places certain limitations on the use of personal information to ensure protection of such information and, where applicable, compliance with the Information Privacy Principles to which Commonwealth Agencies are subject.

(2) The Standard Form Contract for Services does not specifically require service providers to meet national standards although such a requirement may be included in a contract where considered necessary.

(3) There is no general provision in the Standard Form Contract for Services requiring the certification, accreditation or licensing of service providers but again such a provision may be included where appropriate.

(4) There is no current provision in the Standard Form Contract for services requiring service providers to operate consumer complaint mechanisms during the life of the contract. This would be an unusable provision in a conventional commercial agreement but may be applicable in the case of broad grant or funding agreements.

(5) and (10) The consumer can always complain to the Department or the Ombudsman, and other administrative law remedies may be available, but any possible remedy will depend on the particular situation, as will the possibility of complaint to a consumer tribunal.
(12) The Department and the Ombudsman are able to identify systematic concerns to the extent that they receive complaints.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Health and Family Services: Research
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2958)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 12 May 1998:

question.para: (1) What published and unpublished qualitative and quantitative research has been undertaken in relation to each program area of his Department during (a) 1995-96, (b) 1996-97 and (c) 1997-98 including activities planned for the remainder of the financial year.

(2) With respect to each case referred to in part (1), (a) who was the researcher, (b) what was the cost of the research, (c) what process was used to select the researcher, (d) what are the names of other researchers who were approached or lodged tenders and (e) what product was provided to his Department.
(3) In which publications were the results of research referred to in part (1) published.
(4) Are the results of research referred to in part (1) which were not published publicly available; if so, through which departmental contacts.
(5) Will he make the results of research referred to in part (4) available; if not, why not.

(6) Has research been undertaken into the success of (a) marketing activities in print, on radio or on television in relation to programs announced in the (i) 1996-97 and (ii) 1997-98 budgets or (b) campaign activities in print, on radio or on television in relation to (i) illicit drugs, (ii) mental health, (iii) HIV/AIDS, (iv) tobacco, (v) women's health (vi) alcohol and (vii) sexual health.
(7) What was the cost of advertising in (a) 1995-96, (b) 1996-97 and (c) 1997-98, in each program, and what were the activities or campaigns involved.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) to (7) To provide a complete answer to this question would require considerable time and resources and in the interest of efficient utilisation of department resources, I am not prepared to ask my Department to divert from existing priorities at this time.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 13 May 1998:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to questions Nos. 103 (Hansard , 23 May 1996, page 1378) and 2236 (Hansard , 12 May 1998, page 3018), will he clarify (a) the difference between `strict guidelines' and a `number of factors' and (b) whether the factors referred to in part (1) of the answer to question No. 2236 constitute the `strict guidelines' referred to in the answer to question No. 103.

(2) Does he, his office or his Department have a role in the identification of sites for the establish ment of Medicare customer service centres, if so, (a) what role and (b) how was it exercised in determining the 1 7 Medicare offices which were closed in New South Wales.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) There is no difference between `strict guidelines' and a `number of factors'.
(b) Yes.
(2) (a) (b) HIC management makes all decisions regarding the establishment or closure of Medicare offices. I endorse those decisions.

subdebateinfo.title: Rockdale Medical Customer Service Centre: Closure
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2963)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 13 May 1998:

question.para: Did the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) decide to close the Rockdale, NSW, Medical Customer Service Centre without having information about the effects of the (a) substantial upgrading of the St George Hospital at Kogarah, (b) opening in November 1995 of the St George Private Hospital adjacent to the regional hospital and (c) number of patients visiting doctors using the hospitals; if not, (i) should the information have been considered before the decision was made and (ii) will he request the HIC to reconsider its decision.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The answer to this question has previously been provided in Question Nos. 103 and 2236.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 13 May 1998:

question.para: (1) With which countries does Australia have enhanced reciprocal health care agreements.
(2) What changes to the agreement with New Zealand were introduced by the enhanced reciprocal health care agreement which he signed on 4 May 1998.
(3) How does an enhanced reciprocal health care agreement differ from other health care agreements between Australia and other countries.

(4) How many persons entitled to enter Australia through New Zealand were treated under the health care agreement with New Zealand in (a) 1993-94, (b) 1994-95, (c) 1995-96, (d) 1996-97 and (e) 1997-98.
(5) What did the treatment referred to in part (4) cost the Commonwealth and States in (a) 1993-94, (b) 1994-95, (c) 1995-96, (d) 1996-97 and (e) 1997-98.
(6) How many of the persons referred to in part (4) in (a) 1993-94, (b) 1994-95, (c) 1995-96, (d) 1996-97 and (e) 1997-98 (i) were and (ii) were not New Zealand citizens.
(7) How many Australians were treated in New Zealand in (a) 1993-94, (b) 1994-95, (c) 1995-96, (d) 1996-97 and (e) 1997-98 under the same agreement.
(8) What did the treatment referred to in part (7) cost New Zealand in (a) 1993-94, (b) 1994-95, (c) 1995-96, (d) 1996-97 and (e) 1997-98.
(9) With which countries is Australia discussing establishing similar reciprocal health care agreements.

(10) How many persons entitled to enter Australia from each other country with which Australia has a reciprocal health care agreement were treated under the agreement in (a) 1993-94, (b) 1994-95, (c) 1995-96, (d) 1996-97 and (e) 1997-98.
(11) What did the treatment for persons from each country referred to in part (10) cost the Commonwealth and States in (a) 1993-94, (b) 1994-95, (c) 1995-96, (d) 1996-97 and (e) 1997-98.
(12) How many Australians were treated in each other country with which Australia has a reciprocal health care agreement in (a) 1993-94, (b) 1994-95, (c) 1995-96, (d) 1996-97 and (e) 1997-98.

(13) What was the cost of the treatment to each other country referred to in part (12) of treating Australians under the relevant agreement in (a) 1993-94, (b) 1994-95, (c) 1995-96, (d) 1996-97 and (e) 1997-98.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Australia currently has Reciprocal Health Care Agreements with New Zealand, the United Kingdom, Italy, Malta, The Netherlands, Sweden and Finland. A Reciprocal Health Care Agreement with Ireland commenced on 25 May 1998. There is not a category of "enhanced" agreements; rather from time to time an aspect of an agreement is improved by amendment.

(2) The new Agreement with New Zealand has numerous differences in wording made in order to clarify the existing arrangements. The only change in the effect of the Agreement will be that access to Medicare benefits for doctors' and optometrists' services provided on a private basis out of hospital will no longer be available to visitors from New Zealand.

(3) For some years the Agreement with New Zealand has been different from the other agreements in that reciprocity had been significantly reduced as a result of changes to the New Zealand health system in 1992 which resulted in Australian visitors to New Zealand not being eligible for benefits for medical services provided out of hospital. The recent amendment to the Agreement restores reciprocity, making it the same in this respect as the other Agreements.

No two of the Agreements are identical. Variations between Agreements include requirements for eligibility and entitlements. The Agreement with Ireland which came into effect on 25 May 1998 is similar to the amended agreement with New Zealand in that it does not cover medical services provided out of hospital.

(4) Under the agreement which has applied to date, New Zealand visitors to Australia can be treated as public patients in public hospitals, can receive Medicare benefits for doctors' services provided on a private basis out of hospital, and receive pharmaceutical benefits.

Public hospital services are provided by the States and Territories. The Commonwealth does not collect data from the States and Territories on the numbers of public patients treated under Reciprocal Health Care Agreements.
Data on the number of visitors receiving pharmaceutical benefits under the Reciprocal Health Care Agreement is not available.
(a)—(b) Data on the numbers of visitors from New Zealand receiving Medicare benefits in 1993/94 and 1994/95 are not readily available and could not be provided without extensive data re-processing.
Data for subsequent financial years are as follows:

entry.para: No. of visitors receiving Medicare benefits for at least one service

answer.para: (5) The Commonwealth does not collect data from the States and Territories on the costs of public hospital treatment under Reciprocal Health Care Agreements. Data on the costs of pharmaceutical benefits for visitors from New Zealand are not available.
Data on Medicare benefits expenditure under the Agreement with New Zealand are as follows:
* due to changes in data management arrangements
(6) The Agreement covers residents of New Zealand. The Medicare enrolment records do not distinguish between residents who are citizens and residents who are not.
(7) Data on the number of Australian visitors to New Zealand treated under the Agreement are not available.
(8) Data on the costs of treatment of Australian visitors to New Zealand under the Agreement are not available.

(9) Active substantive discussions of possible Reciprocal Health Care Agreements are being held with Norway and Denmark. Enquiries and discus sions with other countries occur from time to time but none of these are substantive and ongoing.

(10) Data on the number of persons from each country receiving public hospital treatment are not available. Data on the number of persons from each country receiving pharmaceutical benefits are not available.
(a)—(b) Data on the number of visitors receiving Medicare benefits in 1993/94 and 1994/95 are not readily available and could not be provided without extensive data re-processing.
Data on the number of visitors receiving Medicare benefits for at least one service in the subsequent financial years are as follows:
(11) As indicated in the answer to question (5), data is not available on costs to the States of providing public hospital services nor on pharmaceutical benefits expenditure.

(a)—(b) Data on Medicare benefits expenditure in 1993/94 and 1994/95 are not readily available and could not be provided without extensive data re-processing, thus incurring additional costs to public outlays.
Data on Medicare benefits expenditure for at least one service in the subsequent financial years are as follows:
(12) Italy has indicated that in 1993 the number of Australian visitors treated was 404. No other data are available.
(13) Italy has indicated that its expenditure for 1993 was 756 million lire. No other data are available.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 13 May 1998:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 2658, (a) what sum has his Department committed to promoting the Job Network, (b) for what period has the sum been committed, (c) for what period will the promotion campaign run, (d) what sum has been allocated to the campaign for (i) radio, (ii) television, (iii) print media and (iv) direct mail, (e) how was the nature of the campaign determined, (f) was his staff involved in developing the campaign, (g) what media research was undertaken before the campaign was determined, (h) what was the cost of the research, (i) how were the companies involved in the campaign selected, (j) what are their names, (k) what sum has each been allocated and (l) for what component of the campaign is each responsible.

(2) Has Employment National committed a sum to promoting the creation of the new government job agency; if so, (a) what sum, (b) for what period has the sum been committed, (c) for what period will the promotion campaign run, (d) what sum has been allocated to the campaign for (i) radio, (ii) television, (iii) print media and (iv) direct mail, (e) how was the nature of the campaign determined, (f) was he, his Department or his staff involved in developing the campaign, (g) what media research was undertaken before the campaign was determined, (h) what was the cost of the research, (i) how were the companies involved in the campaign selected, (j) what are their names, (k) what sum has each been allocated and (l) for what component of the campaign is each responsible.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) As at 19 June 1998 approximately $7.77 million has been committed to promoting Job Network.
(b) Approximately $7.3 million will be spent within the 1997/98 financial year. The remainder is expected to be spent early in the 1998/99 financial year.

(c) The campaign commenced on 26 February 1998. The television component and the major part of the print media campaign finished on 6 June 1998. Other related print media advertising and public relations activity may continue until September 1998.
(d) (i) Radio $189,915; (ii) Television $4,006,446; (iii) Print media $2,142,860; (iv) Direct mail nil.

(e) and (f) The campaign strategy was developed jointly by the Department (DEETYA), the Office of Government Information and Advertising (OGIA), the Office of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and the selected communications consultants.
(g) Initial benchmark research was undertaken to assess job seeker, employer and community awareness levels and identify the information barriers of major stakeholders.
(h) The cost of the initial benchmark research was $74,000.
(i) The engaging of consultants for the campaign followed due process as advised by OGIA, the key components of which are:
. the Department and OGIA developed the brief and compiled a list of consultants who could be invited to tender;
. the Ministerial Committee on Government Communications (MCGC) approved the final brief and the list of consultants to be invited to tender;

. the tenders received were assessed by a committee comprised of representatives from DEETYA, the Office of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and OGIA. As a consequence, two consultants were selected to present to MCGC; and
. final selection of consultant by MCGC.

(j) and (l) The research contract was awarded to Worthington Di Marzio Pty Ltd, the advertising contract to Ammirati Puris Lintas Pty Ltd, and the public relations contract to Wright Business Marketing Pty Ltd. Printing and distribution is being handled under a standing contract with JS McMillan Printing Group.

(k) This is how much they will be paid: Ammirati Puris Lintas Pty Ltd—$1,796,952; Worthington Di Marzio Pty Ltd—$183,450; Wright Business Marketing Pty Ltd—$350,000; JS McMillan Printing Group—$325,000.

(2) The marketing campaign of Employment National, its composition, targeting and commercial arrangements with its contractors, are matters for the Board and management of Employment Nation al itself. Neither I nor my Department or staff were involved in the development of this campaign.
Employment National has provided the following information in response to relevant parts of the honourable member's question:
No, however Employment National did commit a sum to educating the public and potential clients and candidates as to its own existence and role.
(a) $8.4 million.
(c) The campaign ran from 1 December 1997 until June 1998.

(d) As reported in the answer to Senate Estimates Question No. 758, some 41% of campaign funds were spent on television, 11% on radio, 18.5% on print media, 8.6% on direct marketing and the balance on other items of expenditure.
(e) By the Board of Employment National Limited.
(f) No.

(g) Research was undertaken on the brand name and its value, on the proposed market segmentation and market positioning; and on the tag lines and target groups. Benchmarking and tracking research was also conducted.
(h) Approximately $250,000.
(i) By tender and by recommendation.
(j) George Patterson Bates and Keystone Corporate Positioning.
(k) The actual payments in 1997-98 are commercial-in-confidence but were not pursuant to a prior commitment.

(l) George Patterson Bates was responsible for production, distribution and buying of TV, radio, print advertising and direct marketing materials. Keystone Corporate Positioning was responsible for the early research, marketing positioning and market segmentation and project management.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice on 13 May 1998:

question.para: Does he employ Dr James Popple on his staff; if so, (a) how long has he been employed, (b) what is his position, and (c) what does he do.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 14 May 1998:

question.para: (1) What rights do employees of an organisation have to know (a) the precise entity who employs them in circumstances where the entity forms part of an aggregation of companies, trusts and partnerships, (b) the financial position of the organisation and its ability to meet employees' accrued entitlements and (c) about financial transactions entered into by the organisation which may substantially affect its ability to meet the liabilities.
(2) Is he able to say who is the employer of employees at the (a) Hunter Valley No. 1 and (b) Mount Thorley mines.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) In accordance with the Standing Orders, it would not be appropriate for me to provide a legal opinion in response to the honourable member's question. I can indicate, in general terms:

(a) The relationship of employment is created by a contract between the employer and the employee. An employee cannot be transferred to another employer without the employee's consent. It is difficult to see how there could be a concluded contract between two parties without each party knowing the identity of the other; and
(b) and (c) As is the situation with other creditors, an employee has no specific legal right to information about the financial position, or transactions, of the organisation.
(2) I am advised that the employer at both the Hunter Valley No. 1 and Mount Thorley mines is Coal and Allied Industries Ltd.

subdebateinfo.title: Medicare Services: Electoral Division of Port Adelaide
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2986)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 14 May 1998:

question.para: How many Medicare services were (a) provided and (b) direct billed by (i) general practitioners and (ii) specialists in each postcode area in the electoral division of Port Adelaide between 1 July 1996 and 30 June 1997.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Details of the number of services provided, and the number of services direct billed, by general practitioners and specialists in the electoral division of Port Adelaide, based on claims processed by the Health Insurance Commission in 1996-97, are as follows:
General practitioners—Number of services provided—816,097; number of services direct billed—749,328.
Specialists—Number of services provided—234,763; number of services direct billed—118,659.

To provide a complete answer to the honourable member's question would require considerable time and resources to manually review the individual postcode tables and selectively collapse individual categories so as to preserve confidentiality with respect to individual practitioner's practice patterns. I am therefore not prepared to ask my Department to divert the necessary time and resources at this time. Aggregating data up to electorate level overcomes this problem.

Since some postcodes overlap federal electoral division boundaries, the requested data, by servicing provider postcode, have been mapped to electorate using data from the Census of Population and Housing showing the proportion of the population in each postcode in each federal electoral division.

The above data relate to services rendered on a `fee-for-service' basis for which Medicare benefits were paid. Excluded are details of services to public patients in hospital, to Veterans' Affairs patients and some compensation cases.

All practitioners with more than 50 per cent of Schedule fee income from unreferred attendances in the June quarter 1997, were considered to be general practitioners. All other practitioners, including optometrists, and some dentists who can render eligible services, were considered to be specialists. If a practitioner was a general practitioner or specialist in the June quarter 1997, it was assumed that categorisation applied for the whole year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 25 May 1998:

question.para: (1) Is he able to say whether Ashanti, the owner of Cobar Mines, has issued a dividend to its shareholders while former employees and unsecured creditors in Cobar and elsewhere have received a fraction of their entitlements.

(2) Will the Government consider similar arrangements to those proposed in the Stevedoring Levy Bills to enable Cobar mine workers to receive their entitlements; if not, what steps will the Government take.
(3) Is he able to say at what stage is the Australian Securities Commission's investigation into Ashanti's operation in Cobar and when there will be an outcome.
(4) Will the Government introduce legislation to prevent employers from structuring their operations to avoid obligations to employees and creditors; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Ashanti Goldfields Company Ltd (`Ashanti') became the ultimate holding company of Cobar Mines Pty Ltd (`Cobar Mines') following its 1996 acquisition of Golden Shamrock Mines Ltd. Cobar Mines owned and operated the CSA mine until late January 1998 when an administrator was appointed to the company and the mine placed on `care and maintenance'. All employees of Cobar Mines were retrenched on 29 January 1998. A liquidator was appointed to the company in February 1998.

At the time of the retrenchments, the former employees were owed around $10.5 million. The liquidator advises that wages and superannuation entitlements totalling approximately $1.1 million were paid shortly after the retrenchments occurred. Around half of the former employees' leave entitlements, which total nearly $4.0 million, have now been paid. An additional $5.4 million, representing retrenchment pay, remains outstanding.
No payment has been made to any other unsecured creditors. Cobar Mines owes nearly $24 million to various unsecured creditors, including around $5.6 million to trade creditors.

I am advised that the 1997 Annual Report of Ashanti indicates that the company paid a dividend of US20c per share on 109,019,501 shares for the calender year 1997. This dividend was paid on 27 May 1998.
(2) There are considerable differences between the proposed assistance to retrenched waterfront employees and the regrettable circumstances of the former employees of the CSA mine.
The redundancy funding arrangement in the stevedoring industry is only a part of a broader waterfront reform program directed at improving the international competitiveness of the industry.

The waterfront reform program is expected to result in stevedoring companies implementing significant structural changes and to manage the resulting rationalisation of their workforces. The Federal Government's redundancy funding arrangements are intended to assist in meeting the costs of redundancies arising from the reform and restructuring of the industry. They are not confined to any particular employer or group of employees. Funding is not available under this arrangement for redundancies arising where commercial or market circumstances force the closure of a particular business.

The Federal Government considers that the promotion of industry-wide reform is different to the circumstances where an individual enterprise, like the CSA mine, is closed due to commercial or other considerations related to that particular business. Australian stevedores are operating viable businesses that provide the industry with the capacity to repay through levy the funds provided by the Federal Government's redundancy funding arrangements. This means that ultimately the cost will be borne by the stevedoring industry and not by the Australian taxpayer.
In relation to the specific Cobar situation, the Government is considering a request from the Cobar community for assistance for the miners and their families.

(3) I am advised that the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) is continuing its formal investigation into allegations of possible insolvent trading in the period leading up to the appointment of the administrator to Cobar Mines. The ASC is also considering whether any holding company may be liable in respect of any of the debts of Cobar Mines. I am unable to provide any information as to the timing of an outcome from the ASC's investigation.

(4) The issue of how best to protect the entitlements of employees in the event of their employer's insolvency is complex. Accordingly, if legislative action is to be considered by any jurisdiction, it must be practical and effective.

The issue of protecting employee entitlements has been accepted by State and Territory Governments as being, in part, their responsibility. This reflects the fact that these entitlements may be provided for by State or Territory legislation or State awards (as is the case for the Cobar miners).

The Government remains committed to examining how the entitlements of employees can be protected. On 1 May 1998, the Labour Ministers' Council asked the Departments of Labour Advisory Committee to undertake detailed consideration of the issue, including consultation with all affected parties, and report to the next meeting of the Council. The report is to address how employee entitlements are currently protected within jurisdictions and options for improving that protection.
I am aware that the Opposition's Employment Security Bill proposes amendments to the Corporations Law to make corporations liable for the debts of related insolvent companies.

Advice from the Department of the Treasury is that the Corporations Law already provides substan tial protection against asset stripping to defeat creditors. It provides that holding companies can be held liable for debts incurred by their subsidiaries while insolvent.

In addition, Part 5.7B of the Corporations Law contains provisions that allow a liquidator to claw back preferential payments made to any parties in the period leading to the winding up of a company. Where the recipient is a related party, the relevant `claw back' period may be up to ten years, providing substantial protection for creditors from fraudulent arrangements designed to defeat creditors' claims.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, on notice, on 25 May 1998:

question.para: (1) What sum has his Department spent on legal and consultancy fees for waterfront related matters since assuming responsibility for waterfront reform.

(2) With respect to each instance of expenditure referred to in part (1), (a) to whom was the sum paid, (b) for what services was it paid, (c) how were the lawyers or consultants chosen, (d) was a public tendering process involved, (e) on what basis was the sum paid to each person or company involved and (f) were departmental officers seconded to help the lawyers or consultants; if so, (i) what did the secondment cost, (ii) what are the officers' names, (iii) what time did they spend on the work away from their normal duties and (iv) when and where did they perform the work.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Since the transfer of maritime transport responsibilities to the Workplace Relations and Small Business portfolio on 9 October 1997, the sum of $1,435,693.33 has been spent on legal and consultancy fees relating to waterfront reform.
(2) (a) Legal and consultancy costs have been incurred as follows:

(Note: These figures represent the amounts spent by the Workplace Relations and Small Business portfolio. In some cases the figure does not represent the total cost of the consultancy, as payments were made by the Transport and Regional Development portfolio before the maritime transport function was transferred)

entry.para: ACIL Economics and Policy Pty Ltd
Development of industrial relations strategy for waterfront reform
Research and advice on maritime issues
Research and advice on maritime issues
Research and advice on maritime issues
Research and advice on maritime issues
Research and advice on maritime issues
Advice on maritime issues, including in relation to legal proceedings
Advice on maritime issues, including in relation to legal proceedings, and representation in legal proceedings
* This figure represents the sum of the accounts rendered by Dunhill Madden Butler to 30 June 1998. Not all these accounts have yet been paid.

answer.para: (b) The legal costs incurred cover legal advice and representation, including professional advice, counsel fees and other costs incurred in connection with the provision of the advice and representation (eg, travel, court fees, agents' fees, courier and facsimile costs). The consultancy costs cover fees for provision of research, advice and development of options and strategies relating to waterfront reform, plus disbursements.

(c) I am advised that ACIL Economics & Policy Pty Ltd was engaged by the Department of Transport and Regional Development at the request of Minister Sharp on the basis that there was a need to further develop or enhance the tasks previously carried out by ACIL and which required special knowledge and familiarity with the previous task.

I am also advised that Dr Stephen Webster was also engaged by the Department of Transport and Regional Development at the request of Minister Sharp, and that Dr John Davies, Mr David Webb, BGC Media, Minter Ellison, Corrs Chambers Westgarth and the National Institute of Labour Studies were each nominated by Dr Webster and referred to Minister Sharp's office for approval. (Minter Ellison was also engaged separately by the Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business to provide advice on some issues related to waterfront/maritime reform. In that case, the firm was chosen on the basis of its expertise and availability. The cost of that advice ($12,483.88) is included in the figure of $122,769.61 mentioned in paragraph 2(a) above).

In the case of the work performed by Dunhill Madden Butler, I decided that in addition to the services provided by the Australian Government Solicitor (AGS), it was necessary to retain the services of a private law firm to provide advice, and if necessary, representation for the Commonwealth in a range of matters connected with waterfront reform. I asked my Department to compile a list of firms with acknowledged expertise in the areas of law relevant to waterfront reform and selected Dunhill Madden Butler from that list. Consistent with Government policy in connection with the progressive untying of Commonwealth litigation from AGS, my selection of Dunhill Madden Butler to represent the Commonwealth in litigation was referred to the Attorney-General for approval.
(d) No public tendering process was involved.

(e) The basis of payments to AGS, private law firms and counsel engaged by my Department was that fees would be paid for professional services at agreed hourly or daily rates (which vary according to whether particular work has been performed by counsel, partner, senior or junior solicitor) and for costs incurred in connection with the provision of those services (such as travel, court fees, agents' fees, courier and facsimile costs).
Fees and disbursements were paid to consultants on the basis of contracts between the consultant and the Commonwealth.

(f) Departmental officers have not been seconded to help the lawyers or consultants referred to above. However, in the course of their normal duties, Departmental officers have undertaken related tasks such as the preparation of requests for advice, compilation of background material for purposes of obtaining advice and preparing submissions and documents for litigation and provision of instructions in connection with legal and consultancy services.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 25 May 1998:

question.para: Since March 1996, have officers in his Department ordered the conduct of opinion polling, focus group research or other market research on waterfront matters; if so, (a) when did the research take place, (b) who undertook the research, (c) was the research contracted under a tendering process open to all market research groups, (d) how were the persons who undertook the research chosen and (e) were departmental officers seconded to help the researchers; if so, (i) what did the secondment cost, (ii) what are the officers' names, (iii) what time did they spend on the work away from their normal duties and (iv) when and where did they perform the work.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) to (e) My Department has not commissioned or participated in such research. With the approval of the Commonwealth, focus group research was sub-contracted to Australasian Research Strategies Pty Ltd by ACIL Economics and Public Policy Pty Ltd, under its contract with the Commonwealth entered into by the Department of Transport and Regional Development (DTRD), on 16 June 1997. The research was completed before the maritime responsibilities of that portfolio were transferred to my portfolio. The relevant officers of DTRD transferred to my Department on 9 October 1997.

This is a matter relevant to current proceedings in the Federal Court of Australia brought by the Maritime Union of Australia. While those proceedings remain on foot, canvassing this matter outside the Court's processes could prejudice the impartial adjudication of the matter and the rights of the parties to the proceedings.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: To 30 June 1998 the Commonwealth incurred legal costs of $727,169.07 in relation to legal proceedings between Patrick Stevedores Operations No 2 Pty Limited and Others and the Maritime Union of Australia. This amount includes costs incurred in connection with the particular matters to which the honourable member referred.

subdebateinfo.title: British Commonwealth Occupation Forces in Japan
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3004)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 26 May 1998:

question.para: (1) What is the estimated number of Australian veterans who served with the British Commonwealth Occupation Forces (BCOF) in Japan.
(2) Has his Department established a nominal roll of the veterans.
(3) When did the first Australian BCOF personnel arrive in Japan and how many were involved in the initial contingent.
(4) How many Australia personnel, including prisoners of war, were in Japan before the first BCOF contingent arrived and in what locations.
(5) How many other Australian veterans in total were at any time in the vicinity of Hiroshima and Nagasaki between August 1945 and July 1946.
(6) How many BCOF veterans have been accepted for disability pension purposes as having (a) cancer, (b) leukaemia, (c) lymphomas, (d) cataracts, and (e) tumours.
(7) Has his Department ever conducted a health or mortality study of BCOF veterans: if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Approximately 20,000.

(2) Not at this stage. However, my Department has commissioned a study into the feasibility, cost and means of producing a nominal roll of all who have served in the Australian military forces since Federation. A nominal roll for the members of BCOF could be one outcome from this exercise.

(3) February 1946. The Official Historian of the Korean War, Dr Robert O'Neill, in Australia in the Korean War 1950-53, Volume 1 Strategy and Diplomacy, (p32), advised that: "Approximately 11,500 Australians had been sent to Japan by February 1946 to join other service personnel from the United Kingdom, India, New Zealand and Australia to make up the British Commonwealth Occupation Force."

(4) The required information is not available. However, the official history states that at the end of the war 2700 Australian prisoners of war were in Korea, Manchuria and Japan. Australian ships serving with the United States Navy and the British Pacific Fleet operated in Japanese waters before and after the surrender.

(5) It is understood that 26 Australian veterans were in the vicinity of Nagasaki when the atomic bomb was detonated. No Australian veterans were in the vicinity of Hiroshima. Between February 1946 and July 1946 all members of BCOF would have had the opportunity to visit Hiroshima. The numbers who actually did so are unknown.

(6) The required information is not available. Departmental electronic records do not readily enable a distinction between those members of BCOF with Word War II operational service and others who had only served in BCOF. The cost of researching the information is prohibitive.

It should also be noted that the first Australian veterans who served in BCOF arrived in Japan in February 1946, some five months after cessation of hostile action and some seven months after the atomic bombs were dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

By February 1946 the level of radiation present in the environment in Nagasaki and Hiroshima was essentially at normal background levels. In the case of Hiroshima, Professor P L T Ilbery, a leading researcher in this subject, advised my Department on 7 January 1985, that the maximum dose to entrants into the city immediately after the blast had been calculated by studies at 24 units of radiation. By the time Australian servicemen in BCOF entered the city, the residual radiation level calculated to an infinite time would have been less than one unit.

To put this in context, Professor Ilbery provided the following hypothetical example. If a serviceman had been at the middle of the blast area for a whole year from February 1946, his dose of radiation would have been about equivalent to the figure permitted for public exposure by the International Commission on Radiological Protection. This figure for the general public is itself one tenth of the annual dose equivalent limit for those engaged in radiation work.

Information available from some studies indicates that the incidence of cancers among ex-prisoners of war of the Japanese (ex-POWs-J) is the same as that in the control group. One study in particular was published in the 8 September 1960 edition of the New England Journal of Medicine, ie "Delayed Radiation Effects in Survivors of the Atomic Bombings: A Summary of the Findings of the Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission, 1947-1959" by Dr J W Hollingsworth, MD, Chief, Medical Service, Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission; and assistant professor of medicine, Yale University School of Medicine.

(7) No. There has been no evidence found to date that the health of these veterans was different to that of other veterans. A nominal roll would need to be established before such a study could be undertaken (see (2) above).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service upon notice, on 27 May 1998:

question.para: (1) Is he able to say how many persons who were previously employed by the Australian Public Service on a full-time basis are employed by agencies which have subcontracted their services to the Commonwealth
(2) Have the persons referred to in part (1) retained continuity of employment benefits.
(3) Has the Government guaranteed the employment entitlements of the employees in the event of their current employer becoming insolvent; if not, will the Government do so.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No, the APS does not maintain Service-wide statistics on the post-separation employment of persons who leave the APS.

(2) There are currently two approaches for handling the staffing implications of outsourcing in the APS—the Clean Break approach and the Phased approach. The decision about which approach will be adopted is a matter for the outsourcing agency.

Under the Phased approach, provisions are included in the contract which requires the new provider of the outsourced function to meet its additional staffing requirements initially from the pool of staff affected by the outsourcing decision. The outsourcing agency is expected to enter into negotiations with the new provider about employment opportunities for existing APS staff and about the terms and conditions of employment. APS staff who wish to take up employment with the new provider are expected to resign from the APS to do so.

Under the Clean Break approach, the staff currently performing the function are dealt with under the relevant redeployment and retirement arrangements in operation in the agency. The recruitment of staff to perform the function after it is outsourced is left solely to the contractor, who may negotiate directly with staff of the outsourcing agency about future employment prospects and terms and conditions of employment that might apply. There are no restrictions on the future employment of such staff with the contractor. Under the Clean Break approach, the outsourcing agency is precluded from entering into negotiations with the contractor about jobs and/or terms and conditions of employment for staff leaving the APS.

(3) There are no guaranteed employment entitlements for an employee who accepts voluntary retrenchment from the APS and is subsequently successful in obtaining employment with a private sector firm which provides services to the Commonwealth, in the event that the new provider becomes insolvent.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, upon notice, on 27 May 1998:

question.para: Further to the answer to part (4) of question No. 2892, is it a fact that there is no interference between the GSM and analogue signal; if so, why is the analogue system being discarded.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: The decision to phaseout AMPS was not made because of interference problems with GSM. The decision to close the AMPS network on 1 January 2000 was made by a previous Labor Government on competition grounds in 1992.

The ACA advises that GSM mobile phones can interfere with their analogue counterparts. Different AMPS phones experience the interference to varying degrees. It is also a fact that AMPS base stations can interfere with their digital counterparts.

Telstra has advised that it found in the second half of 1993, that some AMPS (Advanced Mobile Phone System) analogue cellular mobile phones can suffer interference from nearby GSM (Global System for Mobile communications) cellular mobile phones operating on a digital service. The interference is from radio transmitter and radio receiver incompatibility.

The severity of the interference experienced depends on the distance between the phones involved and varies from none, through a mild background buzz, up to loss or inability to make a call. The three operators' GSM spectrum allocations are such that subscribers to the Telstra GSM service have the greatest potential for causing significant interference to AMPS subscribers. Subscribers to Optus' service are the next most likely, and subscribers to Vodafone's service are the least likely.

The interference is a result of the two services, AMPS and GSM, operating in immediately adjacent frequency allocations. Telstra's GSM spectrum is closest to the AMPS spectrum, hence the greater potential for Telstra's GSM to interfere with AMPS. The allocations are the standard ones employed throughout the world. AMPS pre-dates GSM by several years but the frequency positioning of GSM was made in a European context that would not have foreseen operation of GSM alongside an AMPS system. The ACA advises however, that there are now more than a dozen countries that operate, or intend to operate, GSM and AMPS systems in parallel.
The measures implemented to address the AMPS interference issue include:

. network engineering; by careful selection of cell site frequencies within their allocations, and by creation of micro-cells in anticipated trouble spots such as airport lounges, the mobile carriers could largely eliminate the potential for interference to AMPS users in such areas;

. warnings; the ACA produces a warning notice advising users of the interference potential of mobile phones. A preface to the advice recommends its inclusion in the documentation and/or packaging accompanying each phone.
. standards; following a program of testing, Standards Australia developed an immunity standard for AMPS handsets.

subdebateinfo.title: Job Placement, Employment and Training Projects
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3017)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 27 May 1998:

question.para: Have funding decisions been made for organisations conducting the ongoing Job Placement, Employment and Training Projects; if so, (a) when will the successful organisations be announced, (b) are the successful organisations spread over all electoral divisions; and (c) has the announcement of the successful organisations been delayed; if so, why.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) An announcement of the organisations which successfully tendered for provision of JPET services was made on 16 June 1998.
(b) The distribution of JPET services is spread across the country, where disadvantaged and at risk populations of young people are highest. There are 102 services covering 75 electorates.
In some instances an organisation may be proposing to provide services across more than one electorate.
(c) No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 2 June 1998:

question.para: (1) How many federal and State police have served in the Australian contingent (AUSCIVPOL) of the UN Force in Cyprus (UNFICYP) and over what period.
(2) How many members of the (a) overall UN force and (b) Australian contingent were killed or seriously maimed during their peacekeeping service in Cyprus.
(3) What repatriation entitlements, including treatment benefits, are available to (a) ADF personnel and (b) police personnel as a result of UN service in Cyprus.

(4) Is peacekeeping, peacemaking or other service under the auspices of the UN considered to be qualifying service for service pension purposes; if so, (a) what are the details and (b) how many veterans are involved.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Australian Federal Police (AFP) estimate that since 1964 about 1,090 federal and State police have served in the Australian contingent of the UN Force in Cyprus.
(2) Fatalities of peacekeeping service in Cyprus:
(a) overall UN force—168 (police: 3; civilian: 3; military: 162) (Source: United Nations).
(b) AUSCIVPOL—3 (Source: AFP).

The total 168 UN force fatalities resulted from accidents (91), illness (40), hostile acts (15), and 22 (other causes). One AUSCIVPOL casualty is reported as resulting from a mine blast, and the other two from vehicle accidents.
No figures are available for those seriously maimed for the UN force or for AUSCIVPOL.
(3) (a) ADF personnel are eligible for disability compensation and treatment for injury or disease arising from their UN service in Cyprus.
(b) Police personnel are similarly eligible for disability compensation and treatment for injury or disease arising from their UN service in Cyprus.

(4) (a) Peacekeeping is not considered to be qualifying service for service pension purposes. Peace enforcement (peacemaking ) is not considered to be qualifying service for service pension purposes, unless it is designated "warlike".

The Department of Defence is responsible for designating service. Since May 1993 the terms "warlike" and "non-warlike" have been employed to classify service which was previously termed "operational".

Warlike service involves the application of force against an armed adversary in conventional situations such as war or peace enforcement operations. If designated as "warlike", ADF personnel and police in peace enforcement operations would be eligible for both service and disability pensions.
(b) My Department has no information on the number of veterans involved in these operations.

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney Opera House World Heritage Listing
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3030)

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 2 June 1998:

question.para: What were the dates and terms of correspondence between the Wran Government and the Fraser Government concerning the nomination which was lodged for the inscription of the Opera House and its setting on the World Heritage List in 1981.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The information provided here is drawn solely from the file records of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.
(2) The dates and terms of correspondence regarding the nomination which was lodged for the inscription of the Opera House and its setting on the World Heritage List in 1981 are:
. Letter dated 11 August 1980 from the NSW Premier's office to the Commonwealth Minister for Science and Environment nominating (inter alia) the Opera House.
. Letter dated 18 August 1980 from the Minister for Home Affairs to the NSW Premier acknowledging receipt of letter of 11 August 1980 regarding World Heritage nominations.
. Letter dated 22 December 1980 from the Acting Prime Minister to the NSW Premier enclosing World Heritage nomination forms for Opera House (inter alia).
. Letter dated 24 December 1980 from the NSW Premier to the Acting Prime Minister giving NSW agreement to (inter alia) Opera House nomination and attaching completed forms.

. Letter dated 5 June 1981 from the Australian Committee on World Heritage Convention to the NSW Environment Protection Division suggesting withdrawal of or variation to the Opera House nomination, due to World Heritage Committee advice that the existing nomination would not succeed.
. Letter dated 19 June 1981 from the Australian Heritage Commission to the NSW Environment Protection Division forwarding documents from Paris related to the Opera House nomination.
. Letter dated 7 August 1981 from the NSW Environment Protection Division to the Australian Heritage Commission regarding variation of the Opera House nomination.
. Letter dated 25 August 1981 from the Australian Heritage Commission to the NSW Environment Protection Division discussing the Opera House nomination.
. Letter dated 11 September 1981 from the NSW Environment Protection Division to the Australian Heritage Commission acknowledging the Commission's letter of 25 August 1981.

. Telex (undated) from the Prime Minister to the NSW Premier regarding the decision to withdraw the Opera House nomination because of the likelihood that it would not be accepted by the World Heritage Committee.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism upon notice, on 3 June 1998:

question.para: (1) In relation to the legal dispute between the CSIRO and Charter Pacific Corporation Limited which was settled in September 1994, (a) were efforts made by either party to settle the dispute without substantial expenditure on legal costs; if so, what form did the efforts take, (b) did Charter Pacific write to the CSIRO in July 1992 seeking to settle the action at that time and (c) when the matter was finally resolved in September 1994, (i) were the final terms approved by the CSIRO Board and the Chief Executive Officer and (ii) was the professional legal advice available to the CSIRO consistent with the final settlement terms.

(2) In relation to the current legal dispute between the CSIRO and Charter Pacific Corporation Limited, (a) have orders for indemnity costs been made against CSIRO; if so, what are the details and (b) what costs for the management of the discovery of documents have been incurred by the CSIRO to the date of answering this question.

(3) Further to the answer to part (3) of question No 2862 (Hansard, 14 May 1998, page 3366), (a) on what basis is the conclusion drawn that a viable resolution would have to involve a full and permanent severance of relations between the parties, (b) is there documentary evidence to support the conclusion, (c) has the CSIRO attempted to resolve the action by offering a settlement on those terms; if not, why not and (d) is the expenditure on legal costs associated with the action consistent with the actual value of the intellectual property in contention.

(4) Further to the answer to part (4) of question No. 2862, (a) did about 5 years elapse between the CSIRO entering contractual negotiations with Charter Pacific and a due diligence study being conducted; if so, what was the reason for the delay, (b) did the due diligence process involve the physical surveillance of any person associated with Charter Pacific; if so, what was the purpose of the surveillance and (c) was relevant information provided to the CSIRO as a result of the due diligence process; if not, why not.

(5) In relation to the legal dispute between the CSIRO and the Cassegrain group, were tape recordings of conversations between senior officers of the CSIRO and members of the Cassegrain group produced in evidence in the Federal Court proceedings; if so, (a) who tape recorded the conversations and (b) were all the recordings made with the knowledge and consent of all persons present at the discussions; if not, what were the circumstances.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) Yes; discussions and a formal mediation.
(b) No; however, I am advised that the company wrote a letter to the then Minister for Science, Industry and Commerce, Senator Button, in July 1992.
(c) (i) The broad terms of the agreement were endorsed by the Board on 15 August 1994 and the final negotiated settlement accepted by the Chief Executive in September 1994.
(c) (ii) All legal advice provided to CSIRO in the context of the settlement remains subject to legal professional privilege.

(2) (a) Orders have not been made about the general costs of the action but an indemnity costs order against CSIRO was made on 29 August 1997 in relation to a specific application by CSIRO designed to protect the confidentiality of information relating to banknotes and other security documents which CSIRO had previously received from its licensees and their customers.
(b) Costs incurred by CSIRO for the management of the discovery of documents in the current matter total $1,139,948.30 to date.

(3) (a) Prerequisites for successful ongoing commercial relationships between parties normally include a reasonable level of trust between those parties; in the view of CSIRO, this prerequisite is not met in the case of Charter Pacific Corporation and is unlikely to exist in the period up to 2006 when present royalty arrangements expire because of the demonstrated propensity of the company to resort to litigation instead of normal methods of resolving differences of opinion.
(b) Yes.

(c) CSIRO has not offered any settlement on those or any other terms; it is inappropriate to comment on the terms upon which CSIRO might be prepared to allow Charter Pacific Corporation Limited to withdraw its action against CSIRO, for CSIRO to withdraw its counterclaim against the company and for all remaining relations between the parties to be severed; however, as a result of discussions between the parties' solicitors and otherwise the company is aware of CSIRO's position in this matter and is free to make an offer to CSIRO embodying those terms at any time; additionally, CSIRO expects that the court will order a routine mediation in due course and the mediation would normally provide a forum in which to consider settlement proposals.
(d) No.

(4) (a) No; the first due diligence was carried out by CSIRO into Charter Pacific Corporation in 1992 and was for the purpose of assessing Charter Pacific's appropriateness as a potential joint venture partner; a second due diligence exercise arose in the context of Charter Pacific having suggested in 1997 that it should become involved in the Exelgram business as more than a passive receiver of potential proceeds from the business; in the intervening period, CSIRO did not perceive any need for information on Charter Pacific that might be derived from a due diligence inquiry.
(b) No; not to the knowledge of CSIRO or its legal advisers.

(c) No; any information likely to have come out of the second due diligence ceased to be relevant once it became clear that any closer relationship between CSIRO and the company was unlikely to eventuate.

(5) (a) (b) (c) A comprehensive answer to this question would require a detailed review of voluminous records associated with the relevant Federal Court proceedings conducted more than 5 years ago; the records are held in archives by CSIRO's solicitors in the matter, Blake Dawson Waldron; however the very substantial professional costs which would be incurred in retrieving and reviewing the records do not appear to be justified.
