talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 22 June 1998:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to comments by Mr Martin Doolan, chief executive of Dental Health Services Victoria in its March 1998 newsletter that more adult concession card holders were having their teeth extracted than a year ago and that the loss of the Commonwealth Dental Health Program was certainly a major factor.
(2) Will he investigate whether the number of teeth extractions is increasing as a result of the loss of the Commonwealth Dental Health Program with a view to taking appropriate remedial action.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (2) No. This is a matter for the Victorian Government.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 22 June 1998:

question.para: (1) What is the Government's position on the importance of the Safety House Program.
(2) What sum did the Commonwealth provide to Safety House Australia Inc. in each financial year since 1992-93.
(3) Did the Government abolish ongoing funding for Safety House Australia from 1997-98; if so, why.
(4) Did the Government subsequently approve a one-off grant of $100 000 to Safety House Austral ia; if so, was the decision to abandon ongoing funding soundly based.
(5) What provision has been made for the continuing operation of Safety House Australia Inc. in 1998-99.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Government is aware of the important community service provided by Safety House Australia. It is a good example of co-operative community based activity with benefits for Australian families and their children.

(2) The Commonwealth provided a one-off grant of $100 000 in December 1997 for the national secretariat activities of Safety House Australia Incorporated only for the 1997-98 financial year. The National Association of Safety House Australia Incorporated was formed in February 1993 with sponsorship from the Medical Benefits Fund of Australia Limited. This sponsorship terminated at the end of 1996.
(3) No. The grant of $100 000 for the national secretariat activities of Safety House Australia Incorporated was one-off for the 1997-98 financial year.
(4) See Answer (3) above.

(5) In accordance with the terms and conditions of the grant, no further provision has been made by the Department of Health and Family Services for 1998-99. In a Letter of Acceptance of grant conditions in January 1998 from the Board of Management of Safety House Australia Incorporated, it was agreed that the grant of $100 000 was to provide one-off financial support to the national secretariat to enable the organisation to work towards becoming financially self sufficient and plan for income generation. The organisation is to report to the Commonwealth by 30 August 1998 on how this grant has been used.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 22 June 1998:

question.para: Have changes been made to flight paths for aircraft departing from Essendon Airport since 1 September 1997; if so, (i) what are the details and (ii) why were the changes made.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Airservices Australia advises that there have been no changes to flight paths for aircraft departing from Essendon Airport since 1 September 1997.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 June 1998:

question.para: Further to the answer to question No. 578 (Hansard , 18 November 1996, page 7035), has his Department produced an estimate of the underlying Commonwealth budget bottom line measured on an expenditure tax basis; if so, what did the figures show regarding the net budget contribution to national saving.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Department of the Treasury does not produce budget estimates on an expenditure tax basis.

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 23 June 1998:

question.para: (1) What human rights issues were placed on the agenda of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General in Perth on 16-17 April 1998 by each Attorney-General.
(2) What was the outcome of each item on the agenda.
(3) Where and when will the next meeting of the Standing Committee be held.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Commonwealth's written report, placed before the April meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, referred to a number of human right issues. These include:
. the Draft Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples;
. ILO Convention 169, (Indigenous and Tribal Peoples in Independent Countries (1989));
. the Commission on Human Rights;
. the Optional Protocol to the Torture Convention;
. the Optional Protocol to the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW);
. the Fourth World Conference on Women;
. possible optional protocols to the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child;
. complaints under International Communications Procedures;
. reporting under International Communications Procedures;
. the joint ALRC/HREOC reference on Children and the Legal System;
. the Inquiry into the Removal of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children;
. the development of Australia's National Policy in respect of Discrimination in Employment and occupation under ILO Convention No 111 (1958)
Other matters included:
. Disability Discrimination legislation and Disability Standards;
. the review of exemptions in subsections 40(2) and 40(3) of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984;
. the reform of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission;
. co-operative arrangements with the States;
. the SCAG Working Group on Human Rights;
. the Human Rights Forum for Non Government Organisations;
. the Decade of Human Rights Education; and
. the review of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975.

(2) These items were placed on the agenda by the Commonwealth in the context of the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Human Rights Paper. This paper serves to inform States and Territories about the activities of the Commonwealth in this area. Matters raised in the Human Rights Paper were noted by State and Territory Attorneys-General.
(3) The next meeting is scheduled to be held in Adelaide on 29—30 October 1998.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Youth Policy Action Coalition: Funding
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3064)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 25 June 1998:

question.para: (1) Has Commonwealth funding been withdrawn from Australian Youth Policy Action Coalition (AYPAC); if so, why.
(2) What sum in Commonwealth funding did AYPAC receive in (a) 1993-94, (b) 1994-95, (c) 1995-96, (d) 1996-97 and (e) 1997-98.

(3) Will AYPAC be replaced by a youth forum; if so, (a) what sum will the Commonwealth provide to fund the forum and (b) how will the new system improve the way in which the interests of young persons are promoted in Australia.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) AYPAC' triennial funding contract with the Commonwealth concluded on 30 June 1998. The Government recently reviewed funding that it provides for secretariat services through peak organisations. The Government has considered the available options for consulting young people and has decided to direct funding towards a new initiative titled Voices of Youth.
(2) (a) AYPAC received Commonwealth core funding of $327,600 in 1993/94. An additional grant of $60,000 was provided to AYPAC to stage Youth Gathering `94.
(b) AYPAC received Commonwealth core funding of $337,400 in 1994-95.
(c) AYPAC received Commonwealth core funding of $347,500 in 1995-96. An additional grant of $60,000 was provided to AYPAC to state a Biennial Youth Gathering in 1996.
(d) AYPAC received Commonwealth core funding of $368,551 in 1996-97.
(e) AYPAC received Commonwealth core funding of $336,008 in 1997-98.

(3) AYPAC is not being replaced. The Youth Roundtables are one of the components of Voices of Youth initiative which provides alternative means whereby young people can ensure their views and concerns are heard by Government. The Youth Roundtables will have 50 members aged between 15 and 24. They will advise the Government on a variety of youth issues including employment, education, health, youth suicide, and youth services.

Further elements of the Voices of Youth initiative include providing financial support to the YMCA National and State/Territory Youth Parliaments to enable broader participation by young people. The Youth Parliaments provide a forum for participants to learn about their Parliamentary system, and to develop skills in debating, team work, leadership and research. The YMCA Youth Parliaments are held annually in most States and biennially at the national level.

In addition, the web site for young people, The Source, for which the Government has provided $110,000 for the design, testing and promotion, significantly enhances the Government's capacity to communicate with young people and for young people to communicate direction with the Government.

Last year the Government provided funding of $3.6m to establish a network of 43 Youth Officers, in the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (DEETYA). The Youth Officers provide feedback to the Government on youth issues and the impact of Government initiatives on young people.

To ensure the views of all young Australians are represented, the Government will be looking to the Youth Bureau of DEETYA to consult directly with peak bodies representing young people across the country.
(a) Funding of $200,000 has been allocated to the Youth Roundtables. Funding of $30,000 has been allocated to support the YMCA Youth Parliaments.

(b) The Government is committed to ensuring that young Australians are given a stronger voice to Government by consulting directly with them. The Government's new initiative, Voices of Youth, will improve consultation processes and enable direct communications between policy makers and young people.

subdebateinfo.title: Sale of Steyr Rifles to Indonesia
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3065)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 June 1998:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to television coverage of recent unrest in Indonesia showing a group of Indonesian soldiers armed with AUG Steyr rifles.
(2) Were the rifles supplied by Australia; if so, (a) were they made by the factory at Lithgow, NSW, (b) how many were supplied and (c) what sum did Indonesia pay for them.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I am aware that the Indonesian Armed Forces possess Steyr rifles.
(2) Australian-produced Steyr Mannlicher Rifles have not been sold to Indonesia.

subdebateinfo.title: HMAS Sydney : Defence Service Homes Entitlement
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3067)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 25 June 1998:

question.para: How many members of the Australian Defence Force who (a) enlisted before 15 May 1985, (b) had an unused Defence Service Homes (DSH) Entitlement and (c) were serving on HMAS Sydney during the revocation period from March to August 1991 (i) accepted and (ii) did not accept the offer to revoke their DSH entitlement for the Defence Home Owner Scheme.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Of the 260 Australian Defence Force personnel who were on board HMAS Sydney during the period March to August 1991:
(a) 156 had enlisted before 15 May 1985.

(b) and (c) 78 had an unused Defence Service Homes Loan entitlement, and served on board HMAS Sydney some time during the period 1 March 1991 to 31 August 1991, when surrender of their Defence Service Homes Loan entitlement in favour of the Defence HomeOwner Scheme was allowed.
(i) 18 of the 78 personnel elected to surrender their Defence Service Homes Loan entitlement, and
(ii) 60 did not accept the offer to surrender their entitlement to the Defence Service Homes Loan.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 25 June 1998:

question.para: In each State and Territory, how many pastoral leases are held (a) in total, (b) by foreign companies and (c) by family firms, families or individual farmers actually involved in primary production.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: I refer the honourable member to my answer to question No. 2569, printed in Hansard on 4 March 1998 (pages 506—508) in relation to pastoral lease holdings.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 29 June 1998:

question.para: (1) How many veterans were receiving a disability pension at the (a) totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) or special, (b) intermediate and (c) extreme disablement adjustment (EDA) rate on (i) 31 December 1995, (ii) 31 December 1996 and (iii) 31 December 1997.

(2) What benefits and concessions in addition to standard pensioner concessions are provided by (a) the Commonwealth and (b) State or Territory governments to (i) TPI, (ii) intermediate and (iii) EDA rate disability pensioners.
(3) What is the estimated annual cost of the additional benefits and concessions referred to in part (2).

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The following table indicates the numbers of veterans receiving above General Rate pensions as at the dates indicated:

(2) Concessions extended to TPI, EDA and Intermediate Rate veterans by State and Territory governments vary and the details are not available. In addition to the standard pensioner concessions available to pensioner concession cardholders, the only concessions understood to be available from the Commonwealth to these veterans are the concessions granted over Commonwealth owned rail track on the Indian Pacific, Overland and Ghan journeys, now operated by Great Southern Railway Ltd. TPI, EDA and Intermediate Rate pensioners all enjoy additional but limited travel on these routes. Clarification of these entitlements with the new owners, however, is still under discussion. It may also be noted that TPI pensioners also enjoy Sales Tax exemptions from the Commonwealth on the purchase of motor vehicles and spare parts.

(3) The cost to the Commonwealth of concessions granted to veterans for travel on former AN services in the 1996/97 financial year was $311, 189. Additionally, Commonwealth revenue was forgone due to the Sales Tax exemptions provided to TPI pensioners but this detail is not known as the Australian Taxation Office does not separately record this information. The cost to State or Territory Governments of concessions granted to veterans would have to be sought from the State or Territory governments concerned. It should be noted that there is a Special Purpose Payment by the Commonwealth to State and Territory Governments for the provision of concessions. This is intended to cover all core concessions including those granted to DVA pensioners on the TPI, EDA and Intermediate Rates. The 1998/99 budget appropriation for this is $151,891,000.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Veterans' Affairs: Mailing Services
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3070)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 29 June 1998:

question.para: (1) Does his Department purchase its mailing services from Security Mailing Services Pty Ltd.

(2) Was Security Mailing Services engaged to mail letters to all recipients of war widows' pensions informing them of changed indexation arrangements for their pension; if so, (a) how many letters were sent, (b) were all letters signed by him and (c) did he decide to sign the letters after the mailing process had commenced; if so, what was the additional cost incurred by his Department as a result of the decision.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) Yes. (a) 97,721 letters were sent. (b) Yes, by facsimile signature. (c) No. However, the letters were printed on incorrect letterhead and required alteration to the salutation. The cost of reprinting was $8,950.74.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 29 June 1998:

question.para: (1) Is it a fact that his Department (a) informed the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs during its consideration of estimates that as at 9 June 1998 the Department had spent $184,850 on research as part of the Government's promised anti-racism campaign for which a provision of $5 million was made in the 1997-98 budget and (b) indicated at page 68 of its portfolio budget statements for 1998-99 that $4.639 million was carried over to the 1998-99 Budget representing an expenditure of $361,000 in 1997-98.
(2) What sum has his Department spent on the anti-racism campaign to the date of answering this question and how has it been spent.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) It is a fact that my Department:

(a) informed the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee during its consideration of estimates that as at 9 June 1998 the Department had spent $184,850 on research as part of an anti-racism campaign for which a provision of $5 million was made in the 1996/97 Budget (not 1997/98 as stated in the question); and

(b) indicated at page 68 of its portfolio budget statement for 1998/99 that $4.639 million was carried over to the 1998/99 Budget. This was, however, a preliminary estimated figure. The final carry-over figure into 1998/99 should be $4.521 million.
(2) To 30 June 1998, my Department has spent a total of $478,588 on the anti-racism campaign. A breakdown for the two financial years follows:

entry.para: Travel, office and staff development expenses
Travel, office and staff development expenses

answer.para: The total expenditure for the period from 1 July 1998 to the date of answering this question (15 July 1998) is not yet available, but is expected to be insignificant.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, upon notice, on 29 June 1998:

question.para: (1) Is it a fact that (a) the Internet Service Provider (ISP) industry is a small business growth industry in Australia and (b) the Government promotes itself as a champion of small business.

(2) Is it also a fact that (a) Telstra is the only Internet Access Provider (IAP) with the infrastructure throughout regional Australia through which ISPs can access the network, (b) no other IAPs allow ISPs to access their regional nodes and (c) Telstra is in direct competition with local ISPs for the provision of Internet services in many parts of regional Australia; if so, does the potential exist for Telstra to misuse its position in the regional Internet market.

(3) What legislative and administrative safeguards exist apart from recourse to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) to ensure that Internet providers like Telstra act appropriately in the regional Internet market place.
(4) Are local ISPs able to complain about Telstra services to the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman; if not, why not.
(5) Within the terms of the telecommunications provisions of the Trade Practices Act, how does the ACCC (a) define the Internet service delivery market and (b) classify organisation as IAPs or ISPs.
(6) How will the competition notices issued by the ACCC to Telstra benefit regional ISPs.
(7) Will he direct the ACCC to investigate Telstra's interconnectivity charging policies in regional Internet markets; if not, why not.
(8) Will he ensure that Telstra does not impose timed local calls upon ISPs for incoming data calls.
(9) Is it inconsistent for Telstra to charge ISPs on the basis of volume of data used but offer individual clients a flat rate of $44 per month for unlimited Internet access.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) The ISP industry may be regarded as a small business growth industry. Various reports place the number of ISPs in Australia at between 500 and 850, most of which fall into the small business category (ie less than 20 employees). The number of ISPs has grown significantly from an estimated 200 in January 1996.

(b) The vast majority of Australian businesses are small. They comprise about 95 per cent of private businesses and number about 900 000. The Federal Government recognises the important role these businesses play, both economically and socially. The Office of Small Business in the Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business has been established as focal point for pursuing Government policy outcomes that benefit, or do not adversely impact upon, the small business sector.
The Office seeks to improve the business-operating environment for small business, and is responsible for:
. providing policy advice to the Government on small business issues;
. building and maintaining effective links with industry, small business organisations, and State and Territory and overseas governments;
. implementing and fostering the Government's small business initiatives; and
. developing an electronic single access point to government business information.

(2) (a) While Telstra has the most geographically extensive Internet `backbone', the networks of other IAPs extend to some regional areas. Regional ISPs may also connect to IAPs other than Telstra's Big Pond Direct, either by dial-up connections at telephony rates or permanent connections by means of leased lines. Which carrier or carriage service provider an ISP approaches for these connections is a matter for the ISP to decide.
(b) No. IAPs other than Telstra do allow ISPs to access their regional `nodes'. Regional ISPs can approach other IAPs to explore alternative means of connecting to the Internet.

(c) Telstra's Big Pond retail units are in direct competition with local ISPs for the provision of Internet services to end users all over Australia, not only in regional Australia. Telstra has advised, however, that it clearly delineates between its IAP business and its ISP businesses. According to Telstra, its ISP businesses acquire carriage and access services from its IAP business on the same terms as are available to any other ISP. As such, Telstra suggests its ISP businesses face the same cost structures as any other Australian ISP with similar economies of scale.

The ACCC has provided the comment that the potential always exists for companies with market power to misuse that power. Telstra has a degree of market power in regional markets for the provision of Internet services. If it should misuse that market power for an illegal purpose, it is open to action under the various laws of Australia including telecommunications specific legislation.

(3) The regulatory framework which was introduced with open competition on 1 July 1997 brought the regulation of competition in the telecommunications industry more closely into line with general trade practices law. All participants in the telecommunications industry are fully subject to the restrictive trade practices provisions contained in Part IV of the Trade Practice Act 1974 (the TPA). The post 97 legislation, however, recognises the scope for Telstra, and other incumbent operators, to engage in anti-competitive conduct. Consequently, there are a number of important mechanisms built into the framework to facilitate vigorous but fair competition. These include a telecommunications access regime, industry-specific anti-competitive conduct regulation, and mechanisms to enable customers to `pre-select' their preferred service provider.

The telecommunications access regime, which is contained in Part XIC of the TPA, establishes clear, legislated access rights for competing service providers to specific carriage services and related services, and establishes mechanisms within which the terms and conditions of access can be determined. The regime is administered by the ACCC and is intended to reduce the market power of those owning or controlling important infrastructure or services which are necessary for competitive services to be supplied to users.

In recognition of the continued market power of incumbent operators, the regulatory framework includes industry-specific provisions for regulating anti-competitive conduct which are contained in Part XI B of the TPA. Under these provisions, the ACCC is able to issue a competition notice to a carrier or carriage service provider which has engaged in anti-competitive conduct. Where such a notice is issued, the ACCC is able to seek pecuniary penalties and a third party will be able to seek damages—if the carrier or service provider continues to engage in the specified conduct.
As the competition regulator, it is appropriate that the ACCC be primarily responsible for addressing allegations of the misuse of market power by Telstra.

(4) No. Only end-users, specifically residential and small business telecommunications consumers, can have grievances investigated by the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman (TIO). The Telecommunications Act 1997 requires all carriers and carriage service providers (including ISPs) to participate in the TIO scheme. ISPs, therefore, participate in the TIO scheme as service providers supplying end users, rather than as intermediate customers of carriers.

This is primarily because the TIO is intended to operate as a scheme to help consumers and small business, not as a dispute resolution forum for telecommunications suppliers. Complaints about alleged anti-competitive issues are normally most appropriately dealt with by the ACCC and about other matters by the ACA.

(5) (a) The ACCC has advised that, as outlined in its information paper, "Anti-competitive Conduct in Telecommunications Markets", it defines markets according to the circumstances dictated by the various investigations it undertakes. This approach derives from the fact that a particular market definition which is pertinent to one investigation may not be applicable in another. Consequently, an ACCC definition of the `Internet service delivery market' is dependent on the particular service being provided, the functional level (wholesale or retail) at which the particular service is provided, whether there are substitutes to the service readily available, the geographic boundaries of a proposed market, the period of time in which the market might be said to exist and, in some cases, on where the effects of particular types of behaviour are being felt.

(b) The ACCC has advised that it classifies organisations as particular types of service provider based on the service in question and with regard to its discussions with the participants in the marketplace and other industry stakeholders. The Competition Notices served on Telstra on 28 May and 17 June 1998 related to its failure to pay IAPs for `access provider services' provided by IAPs while charging those same IAPs for `access provider services' provided to them by Telstra.
For the purpose of those Notices and following extensive discussion with the industry, the ACCC
(i) defined ISPs as the operators of local or regional communications networks from which end users and content providers (the owners of websites) access other similar networks; and

(ii) defined IAPs as the operators of the high speed broadband `backbone' networks for interconnecting the ISP networks in Australia, and having `nodes', or points of interconnection in the major mainland capital cities.

(6) The ACCC has advised that the Notices served on Telstra have resulted in it reaching Internet interconnection agreements with the other three major Australian IAPs. The agreements will substantially lower the costs each of those IAPs incur in providing Internet `backbone' service to ISPs. The savings made as a result of lower costs are apparently already being passed on to ISPs in the form of lower charges for using the major IAP backbones. This has increased competition amongst IAPs for ISP traffic. Regional ISPs are expected to benefit from this increased competition by being able to pick and choose from a wider range of IAPs now able to compete with Telstra for regional ISP business.

(7) Interconnection prices are, in the first instance, a matter for commercial negotiation between the parties. Should service providers seeking access to relevant services be unable to reach agreement on the price-related terms and conditions of access, they may approach the ACCC to investigate the matter and take appropriate action under the general or telecommunications specific trade practices provisions. Concerned ISPs also have certain rights to take private action where they believe conduct breaches relevant provisions.

(8) The Government has prepared draft regulations under the Telecommunications Act 1997 (the Act) to prevent compulsory B-Party charging by carriage service providers of calls to ISPs from residential and charity customers to access the Internet. The Government would not wish to see undermined its legislated guarantee that residential and charity customers have an untimed local call option for data calls.

The Act mandates an untimed local call option for residential voice and data calls, and business voice calls—but not for business data calls. The Government has taken this approach to business data calls on the basis that business users of services have a greater ability to pay for the services they use and should be expected to do so. It is not in anyone's long term interests to establish cross-subsidies that may potentially impact on residential users of telecommunications services. The B-Party charging draft regulations do not, therefore, include business data calls, because the Act does not preclude carriage service providers from charging such calls on a timed basis to the A-Party.

(9) It is not inconsistent for IAPs to charge ISPs a volume based rate while charging individuals a flat rate. It is common practice within the Internet industry for providers to have more than one price which they offer their various clients the different services they provide. The service provided by an IAP to an individual is different to that provided to an ISP and involves different costs and different economies of scale and scope. Differing costs associated with the different product allow providers to set different prices for those products.

Introductory offers are commonplace, as are volume-based discounts, special deals, unbundled pricing and flat rate offers, some of which are up to a year in advance. The variation in pricing packages is consistent with a competitive market where each of the players strive to differentiate their products from those of their competitors.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 July 1998:

question.para: Has the Australian Taxation Office received complaints about the Australian National Aviation College; if so, are the complaints being investigated.

talk.start.para: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: Privacy provisions prevent the Australian Taxation Office from commenting on the affairs of individual taxpayers.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 1 July 1998:

question.para: (1) What procedures exist for the governments of the Commonwealth, the States and the Territories to assess the extent to which the Australian law and practice is in compliance with the provisions of unratified conventions of the International Labour Organisation (ILO).
(2) Has a work plan been developed for the ratification of ILO conventions as a result of the assessment process referred to in part (1); if so, what is the work plan.

(3) Has the Government received recommendations regarding the ratification of ILO conventions as a result of the assessment process or work plan; if so, which conventions have been recommended for ratification.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Commonwealth, State and Territory Labour Ministers adopted a Resolution in 1949 (which has been updated a number of times) that provides a framework for consultation on International Labour Organisation (ILO) matters. The Resolution in its current form makes flexible provisions for the consultative arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories. (A copy of the Resolution has been provided for the honourable Member's information.) It was endorsed by the Labour Ministers' Council on 1 May 1998. The Resolution includes procedures for fulfilling Australia's obligation in relation to Article 19 of the ILO Constitution. That article sets out a process for federations. In Australia's case, this means that newly adopted instruments that are appropriate for action by the various governments in the federation must be submitted to the Commonwealth Parliament within 18 months of their adoption. Those instruments must also be referred to the States and Territories for consideration by them of appropriate action. Australia must report at appropriate intervals as requested by the ILO on the extent to which Australian law and practice conforms with unratified Conventions. All State and Territory Governments are invited to contribute to Australia's periodic reports under Article 19.
(3) Not applicable.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 1 July 1998:

question.para: On what dates, in what form and with what outcomes did the federal Government last consult with State and Territory governments on the ratification of ILO conventions (a) 141—Rural Workers' Organisations, 1975 and (b) 151—Labour Relations (Public Service), 1978.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) On 1 April 1996, Convention No.141 was discussed at a meeting of Commonwealth, State and Territory officials responsible for ILO matters (Technical Officers). At that meeting it was noted that New South Wales, Queensland, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory have agreed to ratification. It was also noted that no other State had identified any difficulties with compliance and most were considering seeking formal agreement to ratification. Formal advice from those States to that effect has not been provided. On 26 March 1997, I wrote to all State and Territory Labour Ministers to confirm this.

(b) Convention No.151 was also discussed at the Commonwealth, State and Territory Technical Officers' meeting on 1 April 1996. At that meeting the Commonwealth indicated that, in light of advice received from the ILO concerning the interpretation of Convention No.151, the Commonwealth had to review its position in relation to the Convention. The ILO advice casts doubt on Australia's capacity to demonstrate compliance. To assist the review, the Commonwealth sought reports from the States and Territories on their compliance status. The reports have not been provided.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 2 July 1998:

question.para: (1) Has the treaty ratification task force completed a review of unratified ILO conventions.
(2) Did the task force consider any conventions to be suitable targets for ratification; if so, (a) which conventions and (b) what action will the Government take in each case.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Government does not have a Treaty Ratification Task Force.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 2 July 1998:

question.para: Has the Government allocated additional funding for the transportation of spent nuclear fuel rods from the research reactor at Lucas Heights, NSW; if so, (a) what additional sum has been allocated and (b) why was it allocated.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Government announced on 3 September 1997 that it had allocated $88 million for the shipment overseas, and reprocessing, of spent fuel arising from the operation of the HIFAR reactor at Lucas Heights. No additional funds have been allocated since that time.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 2 July 1998:

question.para: Has the British Government indicated that it intends to either withdraw from or scale back its activities in the area of nuclear reprocessing; if so, what will be the consequences for the disposal of spent nuclear fuel rods at the Lucas Heights reactor.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: On 5 June 1998, the UK Government announced that there would be no new contracts for commercial reprocessing at Dounreay, Scotland. This announcement relates only to activities at Dounreay—it does not affect reprocessing activities undertaken elsewhere in the UK.

The announcement does not affect the 114 spent fuel elements shipped to Dounreay in 1996, as these fuel elements have already been processed. It does, however, mean that Australia has to utilise the services of another organisation for reprocessing the balance of the spent fuel, which is of UK-origin. Action to do so is in train.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 2 July 1998:

question.para: (1) Has the Government received reports on the success of the 1998 World Expo in Lisbon, Portugal; if so, (a) what do the reports reveal about the trading and tourist opportunities which were available to exploit at that Expo.
(2) Given that Australia was unsuccessful in its bid to host Expo 2002 on the Gold Coast, will Australia participate in the Year 2000 Expo in Hanover.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (2) The German Government was advised in December 1997 of Australia's intention to participate in Expo 2000.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 2 July 1998:

question.para: (1) Will he provide a list of federal electoral divisions in which funds have been received under the Jobs Pathway program in each round since 2 March 1996 showing (a) the sum received under the program; and (b) the percentage rate of youth unemployment in the electoral division.
(2) Will he provide a list showing the percentage rate of youth unemployment during the period referred to in part (1) in electoral divisions which did not receive funds under the program.
(3) Will he provide precise details of (a) the selection process for successful program brokers; and (b) his or his office's involvement in the selection process.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No program administered by my Department is funded on the basis of federal electoral division. With regard to the Jobs Pathway Program (JPP), there have been two tender rounds since this Government came to Office in 1996: 1996-97 and 1997-98.

(a) A meaningful break down of funding by electorate is not possible for two reasons: funding decisions for JPP are not made by electorate and the brokers have been contracted to provide assistance to students up to an agreed target for a region which may cover more than one electorate. However, I have asked the Department to map the provision of JPP services across to federal electorates and the attached table shows the number of schools in each electorate at which students are receiving (or have received) assistance from a JPP broker.

(b) Information about the percentage rate of youth unemployment by electorate is not routinely maintained by my Department. However, the Parliamentary Library has recently compiled a set of data for each electorate that includes the percentage rate of youth unemployment which has been derived from the 1996 Census data. This information is included in the attached table.

(2) There are six federal electorates in which assistance under JPP has note been available: Cook, Gilmore and Throsby in NSW, Fairfax and Fisher in Queensland, and Franklin in Tasmania. Information about the percentage rate of youth unemployment by electorate is not routinely maintained by my Department. However, the Parliamentary Library has recently compiled a set of data for each electorate that includes the percentage rate of youth unemployment which has been derived from the 1996 Census data. This information is also included in the attached table.

(3) I have directed my Department to provide information about the general nature of the selection process used for both 1996-97 and 1997-98 only. This general information is attached. Neither I nor my office have had any involvement in the selection process for the Jobs Pathway Program.

para.inline: NUMBER OF SCHOOLS BY ELECTORATE AT WHICH STUDENTS HAVE BEEN ASSISTED DURING 1996/97 & 1997/98

answer.para: 1996-97 Jobs Pathway Program—Tender Process

. For the 1996-97 round, the focus of the Program was on assisting those school leavers, who had successfully completed their Year 12 studies and had undertaken vocational education courses as part of their Year 11 and Year 12 studies, to obtain employment, including traineeships and apprenticeships, and provide advice and support over the first year of their placement.

. Given the relatively low numbers of Year 11 and 12 students participating in vocational education courses, the Department adopted a selective tendering process, choosing organisations recommended by its Area Offices as having the potential to become JPP brokers. These organisations were invited to submit tenders.

. The criteria for determining which regions received priority for funding under JPP for 1996-97 were that there should be sufficient numbers of students undertaking a school based vocational education programs and that appropriately qualified brokers existed to deliver the program. Quantification of the numbers of students participating in school based vocational education programs was drawn from the survey performed by the Australian Council for Educational Research on behalf of the Australian Student Traineeship Foundation.

. Tenders were assessed against the objectives of the program and for consistency with the national strategic objectives in vocational education and training. The principle of value for money was applied through this process.
. Contracts were executed with 40 organisations to manage 42 projects.
1997-98 Jobs Pathway Program—Tender Process

For the 1997-98 round, the focus of the program was expanded to providing assistance to school leavers to find and sustain employment as well as to work with those students who would otherwise leave school without completing their year 12 studies, with a view to encouraging them to remain at school.

An open and competitive tender process was adopted and tenders were called through advertisements in the national and major regional press on 7 and 11 June 1997. Organisations wishing to tender had a six week period to 18 July 1997. Copies of the tender documentation could be downloaded from the DEETYA Home Page on the Internet.
. The tender documentation clearly specified the:
- objectives of the program (section 3);
- range of services that are expected to be provided by brokers (section 4);
- outcomes expected (section 5);
- use of placement and retention targets as a measure of performance (section 6);
- roles and responsibilities of both DEETYA and brokers (section 7);
- funding and reporting arrangements (section 8); and
- tender process (section 9).

. Section 9.2 clearly specified the outcomes that we were seeking from the tender process, namely quality brokerage services, quality vocational guidance, open competition, value for money and ethical and fair dealings, accountability and impartiality.

. Section 9.3 specified how tenderers should define a region for JPP for 1997-98. It clearly indicated that the final shape of each region may vary according to a number of factors including the number of schools, numbers of students, level of participation in VET programs, Year 12 completion rates, level of youth unemployment and the broker's capacity to deliver the services. Tenderers were asked to nominate their region by specifying the schools that they intended to work with if successful. The tender document clearly indicated our intention to contract some 70 brokers/regions for 1997-98 and clearly states the intention to rank regions nominated by tenderers. The basis for ranking was stated as youth unemployment and Year 12 completion rate. A typical size region was specified and allowance made for schools in smaller communities (regional and remote) to tender and receive the same level of consideration as tenders from more typical regions.

. Section 9.5 stated that tenders would undergo an initial assessment by DEETYA officers with knowledge of each region—this initial assessment took place in the DEETYA State Offices. The ranking of regions and subsequent shortlisting of tenders took place in DEETYA National Office. The final shortlisting took account of value for money and potential overlaps between regions.

. Negotiations with shortlisted tenders were undertaken to confirm the region/s nominated and the targets proposed for job placement and school retention. Contracts were executed with 63 organisations to manage 68 projects.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 2 July 1998:

question.para: (1) Are part (6) of the answer to question No. 2596 (Hansard , 22 June 1998, page 5073) and part (20) of the answer to question No. 2918 (Hansard , 22 June 1998, page 5073) contradictory; if so, which is correct.

(2) Do the minutes of the GMAC meetings identified in part (16) of the answer to question No. 2918 state or note that the GMAC members identified in the question stood aside from the discussions about plants carrying viral genes; if so, do the minutes state that the GMAC members stood aside (a) in every one of the meetings and (b) from every one of the discussions.

(3) Are GMAC members (a) directly involved in projects to develop genetically engineered organisms or (b) employed by organisations, institutions or companies involved in projects to develop genetically engineered organisms; if so, (a) which GMAC members, (b) which organisations, institutions and companies and (c) what kinds of genetically modified organisms.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) While none of the GMAC members are practising plant virologists or experts in plant virus recombination, two members are sufficiently know ledgeable in the areas of plant virology and plant virus recombination to be able to provide a well-informed input to GMAC in these areas. This is the source of any apparent contradiction in the two answers.

(2) The members (Dr Oakeshott and Dr van Heeswijck) identified in part (16) of the answer to question No. 2918 did not stand aside from the discussions about plants carrying viral genes at the meetings referred to in that answer because they had no conflict of interest in the proposals. Neither Dr Oakeshott nor Dr van Heeswijck were involved in any of the nine proposals involving virus-resistant transgenic plants discussed at meetings they attended. Dr Oakeshott was present at a meeting (Scientific Subcommittee meeting on 2 July 1992) at which one proposal originating from the organisation that employed him (CSIRO) was discussed. That proposal involved virus-resistant transgenic potatoes and was submitted by CSIRO Plant Industry. Dr Oakeshott is employed in a different Division of CSIRO (CSIRO Entomology) and had no involvement with the project; he was therefore not considered to have a conflict of interest.
(3) (a) Yes, because practising experts in genetic manipulation are essential for GMAC's function.
(b) Yes.

(a) Professor Angela Delves, Professor Ashley Dunn, Professor Peter Hudson, Professor Staffan Kjelleberg, Associate Professor Peter Langridge, Dr John Oakeshott, Professor Jim Pittard, Dr Jan Tennent and Dr Robyn van Heeswijck are directly involved in projects to develop genetically engineered organisms. Professor Byron Lamont, Professor Nancy Millis and Associate Professor Loane Skene are employed by organisations involved in projects to develop genetically engineered organisms.

(b) Southern Cross University (Delves), Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research (Dunn), CSIRO (Hudson, Oakeshott, Tennent), University of New South Wales (Kjelleberg), Curtin University (Lamont), University of Adelaide (Langridge, van Heeswijck), University of Melbourne (Millis, Pittard, Skene).

(c) Genetically modified rice and barley for cold tolerance and improved malting quality (Delves); genetically modified mammalian cells, microorganisms and laboratory animals for cancer research (Dunn); genetically modified microorganisms and mammalian cells for studies of gene expression (Hudson); genetically modified microorganisms for studies of bacterial survival in the environment (Kjelleberg); genetically modified wine yeasts with altered properties, genetically modified wheat and grasses with altered breeding properties, and genetically modified wheat for improved baking quality of the wheat flour (Langridge); genetically modified microorganisms and insects for development of biological insecticides and bioremediation (Oakeshott); genetically modified microorganisms for studies of gene expression (Pittard); genetically modified microorganisms for vaccine studies (Tennent); genetically modified grapevines for disease resistance (van Heeswijck).
The organisations that employ Professor Lamont, Professor Millis and Associate Professor Skene are involved in projects to develop a very wide range of genetically modified organisms.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 2 July 1998:

question.para: (1) What offers have been forwarded by each Commonwealth department and statutory authority to each consultant selected for the panel of suppliers established by his Department under competitive tendering and contracting for the provision of (a) legal services, (b) project management services, (c) management consulting services and (d) change management services and advice.
(2) Which consultants referred to in part (1) have received contracts to undertake a consultancy.
(3) What is the dollar value of each contract referred to in part (2).
(4) Have contracts been let to consultants outside the panel; if so, in each case, what is the (a) name of the consultant and (b) dollar value of the contract.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1)—(3) The use of the panel of consultants to assist departments with their Competitive Tendering and Contracting approach (CTC) is not mandatory. Individual Government departments are not required to report their usage of the panel to the Department of Finance and Administration. Statistics on use of the panel are therefore not collected. However, Government departments are required to gazette all contracts arranged with a value above $2,000 in the Commonwealth Purchasing and Disposals Gazette.

(4) The decision on whether a Government department uses a consultant from the panel or not, rests with the individual department. Government departments are required to gazette all contracts arranged with a value above $2,000 in the Commonwealth Purchasing and Disposals Gazette.

subdebateinfo.title: Disposal of Gona Barracks, Kelvin Grove
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 3112)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 July 1998:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 1310 (Hansard, 13 May 1997, page 3425) concerning the disposal of Gona Barracks, Kelvin Grove, Qld, has his Department developed a specific disposal strategy; if so, will he provide a copy; if not, why not.
(2) Has consultation with key stakeholders, relevant authorities and members of the local community been undertaken; if so, what are the details; if not, when will it be undertaken.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No. A specific disposal strategy is presently being developed. A planning manager, who is responsible for the development of an appropriate disposal strategy, was appointed on 10 July 1998.

(2) No. However, preliminary consultation has commenced with Queensland State Government, Brisbane City Council and the Turrbal Clan advising of the future closure and disposal of the facility. An integral part of the disposal strategy being developed will be an extensive consultation process involving key stakeholders, appropriate federal, state and local government authorities, interested parties and the local community. It is anticipated this consultation process will commence in late August 1998.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 2 July 1998:

question.para: Further to the answer to question No. 3021 (Hansard , 2 June 1998, page 4236), what was the total cost to the Commonwealth in precise dollar terms of his 1997 Christmas function held at Kirribilli House.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: I have nothing to add to my previous answers to questions No. 3021 and No. 2633 (Hansard of 1 July 1998 and Hansard of 13 May 1998 respectively).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 15 July 1998:

question.para: (1) Has the Australian Defence Force (ADF) decided to acquire aerial target drone towing aircraft from the US company, Tracor Flight Systems, ahead of tenders from Australian companies like ADI.

(2) Is he satisfied that the selected tender was the best available to meet the ADF's needs; if so, (a) why was Tracor Flight System's tender the best available and (b) will awarding the contract to a foreign company benefit Australia more than awarding it to an Australian company; if so how.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes, the contract to supply the Kalkara Aerial Target System is with Tracor Inc. ADI was but one of several Australian based companies that tendered to supply an aerial target system to replace the Jindivik target system.
(2) Yes, I am satisfied that the selected tender was the best available to meet ADF needs.

(a) After an exhaustive evaluation, the MQM-107E target system offered by Tracor Flight Systems was assessed as the best available to meet the ADF's long term needs and, in doing so, represented the best value for money. My media release, MIN 120/96 of 21 November 1996, a copy of which I have forwarded to your office, referred to outcomes of the evaluation of tenders.

(b) In each tender the target aircraft would have been sourced from overseas and operated by Australian based companies. The Tracor Flight Systems tender was no different in this regard with Aerospace Technologies of Australia, now Boeing Australia, sub-contracted to operate and maintain the system through to 2007.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 15 July 1998:

question.para: (1) Has an application been made by the Catholic systemic schools system to be funded by the federal Government at category 11.
(2) Have the schools been assessed as meeting the criterion of need to receive the additional funding.

(3) What (a) extra funding per primary student, (b) extra funding per secondary student and (c) average extra funding per student overall in the Catholic school systems would result if the funding application was successful.
(4) What is the progress of the application referred to in part (1) and will he approve the application.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) All State and Territory Catholic Education Systems, with the exception of the Western Australian and Australian Capital Territory Systems, are seeking category 11 funding from the Commonwealth. The Australian Capital Territory System applied for category 11 funding in November 1997 but withdrew its application in April 1998. The Western Australian System already receives category 11 funding.

(2) In order for a System to be re-categorised, the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1996 requires a System to demonstrate that a significant change in financial need has occurred due to circumstances outside its control. Applications must be submitted to the Non-Government Schools Funding Review Committee (NGSFRC), an independent body which reviews each case and makes a recommendation to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training.

(3) If the funding applications were successful, the extra funding (based on 1998 rates) would be: (a) $155 per primary student; (b) $224 per secondary student; and (c) an average of $180 per student for the Catholic school systems seeking a review.
(4) All the Catholic Systems seeking re-categorisation to category 11 have had their appeals considered by the NGSFRC.
